Jon was appeased by that and led his wife out of the great hall and through the open courtyard that had the map of Westeros painted over the floor. She stood in the center and sighed as she looked around. “The world is much bigger than this,” she said softly. “Essos, YiTi, Naath...” she looked up at him and wrinkled her brow. “You allowed the Wildlings beyond the Wall. I brought the Dothraki and Unsullied with me.”


He nodded, following her thoughts. “We’ll work to unite the world. Welcome those from other places. Make others realize that in a lot of cases it’s only location that divides us.”


She gave him a smile and nodded. “Some of the Lords and people here will be against it,” she said, tilting her head as she linked her arm through his.


“We’ll lead by example. Send out word to other countries and islands that we welcome diplomats to open conversation. Possible trade.”


As they exited to the breezeway, she stopped for a moment and looked at him, taking a deep breath. “I love you.”


His face softened as he looked upon her worried expression. He removed her hood and placed a kiss on her lips. “And I love you.”


She took another steadying breath and released, her face transforming into her serene queenly visage. “I’m ready.”


*~*


Daenerys sat amongst the children of the orphanage, one dark-haired little boy on her lap as she listened to him tell how his mother had put him there after his father had sailed off with Euron’s fleet. Jon looked around, noting the curious faces and wondered if they had enough food, clothing, beds. If they were safe.


The matron leaned over and whispered in Jon’s ear. “His mother told me she was dying. She wanted him here before that happened so she could say goodbye while she was still well.”


Jon looked up at her and gave her a slight nod.


“And are the others treating you well?” Daenerys asked him.


The little boy nodded enthusiastically. “Thomas shares his food wit me sometimes!”


Daenerys smiled. “And who is Thomas?”


A little boy with sandy blonde hair raised his hand. He was seated toward the back and Daenerys bid him come forward. He made quick bows to them both, Jon hiding a smile behind his hand. “That is very kind of you to do, Thomas,” Jon said.


“The bigger ones have ta take care o tha little ones.”


Daenerys nodded with a smile. “We all get on better when we take care of each other.”


The little boy was quiet for a moment then blurted, “Are yur dragons gonna eat us?!”


A murmur filtered throughout the room and Jon could see the fear in their little faces. However, Daenerys raised her hand and the room fell quiet. “Drogon, the large black dragon, and Rhaegal, the green dragon, are my children. I hatched them in a fire,” she said as if she was telling them a secret. “They helped us fight off the dead and bring peace to the city. Do you think they would go through all that trouble just to eat you?”


Thomas tilted his head at her, his brow furrowed, his lips twisted in thought. “I don’t think so.”


Jon smiled. “The dragons like to fly and hunt in the woods. I don’t think you have to worry about them.”


“And do you really ride em?”


Jon nodded. “I ride Rhaegal and the Queen rides Drogon.”


“Is it scary?”


He chuckled. “Almost as scary as standing on top of the Wall for the first time.”


Thomas looked at Jon’s sword and tilted his head as he examined it. “Is that a wolf?”


Daenerys answered before he could. “The Direwolf is the sigil of House Stark. It’s the sword that helped Jon kill the Night King.”


Several of the children gasped. “The Night King is a story!” one of them exclaimed.


Jon sighed. “The Night King was very real. But he’s gone, now. The Queen, the dragons, and our armies helped defeat him and his army.”


“And you used that sword?”


Jon stood and pulled it from its sheath, and held it horizontal in his hands. “The sword is named Longclaw. It was given to me by Lord Commander Mormont,” he replied. “It’s Valyrian steel which means it’s always sharp.”


“Can I touch it?”


Jon resheathed it with a chuckle. “No. You touch it and cut yourself and people will think I’m a bad king.”


Daenerys smiled up at him as she let the little boy climb from her lap. He held out his hand to her. “Now, we expect all of you to behave,” he told them, helping her stand.


Little heads nodded as Jon signaled for the matron to follow them. When out of earshot of the children he looked at his wife, sharing a silent thought. He turned to matron. “What do you need from us?”


The older woman looked at the children and she gave a heavy sigh. “Some repairs to the building. Food. Clothes...the last queen cared nothing about them. Queen Margaery did, but even she seemed distracted towards the end. We’ve accumulated more orphans than we have room to keep.”


Daenerys spoke first. “We’ll have tailors begin work on clothes for the children and cobblers on shoes. We’ll also make sure that food is delivered here on a weekly basis for meals throughout the week,” she took a breath and looked to Jon. He felt the weight of what they were working with and against settle between them.


“We’ll also send a request to the Citadel for a Maester specifically for this place. They should grow up with an education and someone to look after their health,” he added.


The smile on Dany’s face melted him. “Until then,” she said as she turned back to the woman. “We’ll ask around for someone who can do the repairs to your building and should you need more room, we’ll try to find somewhere bigger to house you all. And please, come to the Keep, ask for Missandei should you need anything. She will be the one to get you an audience with us. And we would like to see you if you need anything.”


The surprise on the woman’s face melted into a watery smile and she bowed at both of them.  “Thank you, Your Graces,” she said and looked back at the children. Jon noticed that the room was still watching them in fascination. “The children will speak of this day for a long time.”


Jon gave her a nod before following Daenerys out into the street. He helped her mount her horse, she was still refusing to ride in a carriage. The Unsullied marched beside them as they rode through the street and back toward the keep. People had lined the streets with Targaryen banners and cheered them as they walked through. They stopped outside the Red Keep, their horses taken away as some of the people came closer for a glimpse at their new King and Queen.


Daenerys’s voice silenced the chatter, “Spread the word that tonight we lay to rest a hero of Westeros, my Hand, Tyrion Lannister. Come to the ruins where the Sept of Balor once stood and see his pyre and pay respects to the man who once saved this city and who helped unite this kingdom against its enemies.”


She turned to face Jon and he offered his arm. They reentered the keep and were met by Sam. “Raven from Storm’s End,” he said, offering it out.


Jon took it and broke the seal. He took a deep breath and scowled. “Gendry and Arya were attacked by Faceless Men.” He looked up at her. “Gendry was stabbed three times with a poisoned blade.”


Daenerys gripped his arm tighter. “Are they alright? Gendry?”


He heaved a sigh. “Arya said that they managed to stop the poison.” He shook his head and ran a hand down his face. “It’s bad enough dealing with an enemy you know is real. But how would you be able to trust even your lover if those faceless assassins are lurking around?”


Daenerys frowned. “You wouldn’t. We put them in danger,” she whispered.


Jon wrapped an arm around her shoulders. “Let's send some of the Unsullied to Storm’s End if they want to go.” He took a deep breath and kissed her brow. “We need to go to our room and talk.”


She nodded and allowed him to lead her, smoothing her hands over the swell of her stomach. The Unsullied guards opened the door for them and she immediately went to the hearth to check on the eggs as he noticed Ghost was lying across the foot of the bed. He removed his cloak, draping it over a chair. She walked away from the hearth and took a seat at the table across from him. She removed her cloak and the sight of her reminded him that she was still mending from wounds. He pulled his chair closer and turned her head to allow him to look at her stitches. “No more headaches?”


“No,” she said as she took his hand. “I’m feeling fine, physically. Just tired. It’s my heart that hurts,” she whispered and turned to look at the hearth. “I know how to wake the eggs, Jon.”


He glanced at them and back at her. “I’m listening.”


“We’ll put them on Tyrion’s pyre,” she declared. “Only death can pay for life.” He let out a slight laugh, feeling the pain of the statement but seeing the humor at the same time.


Her pained expression turned to one of confusion. “Are you laughing at me?”


He shook his head, lowering his eyes to look at his fidgeting hands. “No. I feel Tyrion’s loss greatly. He was one of the first people to ever be truly honest with me about the world and what I was signing up for. He never walked away from telling me the truth and I always,  always respected him. He was a brilliant man and having him believe that I would be a good king and someone worthy of being at your side meant...” He shook his head unable to finish his sentence. He collected himself and looked up at her, again. “Imagine him looking upon us speaking of him so highly. And then imagine if his sacrifice, his life, is the one that helps breathe more dragons into the world. We wouldn’t be able to shut him up about it.”


She gave him a watery chuckle and nodded. “He’d be nearly impossible to be around.”


“Lord it over all of us until we pitched him out of the room,” he said, the sadness creeping back in. “How many things would he be telling us we’re doing wrong, you think?”


Daenerys smiled and took his hand. “A lot, probably. But we have Davos, Missandei, and Varys. We have people we can trust to help us make the world better.”


“We have each other, too,” he said squeezing her hand. “We’re going to fix this world, Dany, and if we can’t get it done during our lifetime, then we’ll prepare our daughters to do so.”


She gave a smile. “I love you.”


He kissed the back of her fingers. “I love you, too.”


*~*


They stood at the edge of the pyre. She'd brought the eggs in a basket, carrying it in her arms. She handed it to him. “Can you put them on there for me? I can’t reach.”


He placed a kiss on her head. “I’m not much taller than you,” he whispered.


She smirked. “You’re tall enough,” she replied.


He placed the eggs above Tyrion’s head and looked down at the man once more. He felt a deep ache in his heart and sighed. “Thank you, my friend.”


He returned to Daenerys. Jaime stood at her side, leaning on a crutch. “Your brother and I didn’t always agree, but that’s why I chose him as my Hand. He cared about what happened to people,” she said to him and he watched as tears rolled down Jaime’s face. “I will let you light the pyre, or I could let the dragons do it.”


He took a moment, looking at her and Jon, both waiting for his decision. “Tyrion had a flair for the dramatic. Let the dragons do it.”


Daenerys nodded and soon both dragons were on the ground, the people gathered looked terrified but awed at the same time. “A great sept once stood here. Built to worship the seven gods. And a queen destroyed it for ambition,” Daenerys’s voice carried over the murmur of the people. “Tyrion Lannister came to me after he fled King’s Landing. He didn’t agree with everything I said, he challenged my opinions and thoughts of what Westeros was. And it was because of this that I made him an advisor, and then my Hand.” Jon was amazed she was holding it together so well.


She took a deep breath. “When I first landed in Westeros, I wanted to fly my dragons to the Red Keep and burn it and everyone inside. Tyrion cautioned me not to do that. He reminded me that I didn’t want to rule the ashes. That the people were innocent and didn’t deserve such a fate.” She looked out over the masses. “Tyrion cared about what happened to you. He wanted you to have better lives. I respected him as my Hand and I loved him as a brother. This world has gone darker without him in it. The King and I will do everything in our power to make sure the dream of giving you that better life comes true.”


She took Jon’s hand and gave it a squeeze. “It is custom among the Dothraki and the Wildings to burn bodies and send them to the heavens as a warrior tribute. No one deserves it more than Tyrion.” She looked at Drogon, then Rhaegal. “Dracarys.”


A small burst of flame came from each dragon and lit the outer circle. Daenerys took off her cape and handed it to Jon. She pressed a kiss to his lips and started walking to the pyre, but his hand caught her wrist. “What are you doing?”


She reached up and cupped his face. “I’m going in to get my children,” she whispered. “Stay here until the fire burns away.”


“I’ve seen you walk through enough fire, Daenerys.”


“It won’t hurt me. Trust me, my love.”


He couldn’t shake the fear that nearly choked him, but he released her and the people gasped to see her walk into the flames.


Jaime moved closer to Jon. “How are you so calm watching her walk into another fire?”


“She lived through the others, didn’t she?” he answered. “Sometimes, when it comes to my wife, it’s best not to question the magic that flows through her veins.”


“What about your veins?”


He shook his head and looked down at the cloak draped over his arm. “She’s the one who brought dragons into the world, again. She is the Mother of Dragons. I have to let her be who she is.”


Jaime nodded and stared at the fire. “Thank you, for giving this to Tyrion. I wouldn’t want him buried in the tomb with my sister.”


Jon looked over at him and frowned. “No, I don’t imagine you would. Now, the world knows you’ll hold true to your word,” he said softly. “I’ll no longer allow people to disparage you by calling you Kingslayer.”


“Kinslayer. Queenslayer. Oathbreaker. All names I’ve earned.”


“Since you rode North, you’ve attempted, if not succeeded in keeping your word. I trust that you’ll continue to be someone we can trust, my Lord.”


“The heir of House Lannister pledges his loyalty to House Targaryen.”


Jon gave him a nod. “I believe you.”


*~*


As sunlight rose over the kingdom, the fire finally died away. The Unsullied and the Dothraki had stayed vigilant near the pyre. As did he, pacing until the last of the white smoke had drifted into the sky. Now they all stood, staring in awe.


There, in the middle of the burnt out pyre was his wife, a dragon nestled on her shoulder. Jon stepped over the smoldering ashes and held out his hand to her and helped her from the ground. The hatchling on her shoulder moved down her arm and over to his.


The sound of metal all creaking at once echoed through the air as the Unsullied bent the knee. The Dothraki fell to their knees as well and bowed to her. Three other dragons crawled up and along her body as Drogon and Rhaegal screeched overhead.


Jon looked up at the early morning sky to see them and noticed a red comet streaking across the dawn. Davos’s voice echoed over the murmurs of the townsfolk. “HOUSE TARGARYEN!  LONG MAY THEY REIGN!”

“HOUSE TARGARYEN! LONG MAY THEY REIGN!” the people echoed back, cheering. Missandei provided her cloak, wrapping it around her naked body as Jon allowed the dragons to crawl from her to him.

Chapter End Notes

Next chapter: Bran - yeah, we're gonna catch Winterfell up with the current timeline as I now have Arya/Gendry and Jon/Dany all along the same path. So, expect Bran, Sansa, and Meera for the next three chapters.

Bran II

Chapter Summary

The Warden of the North finds new ways of helping people while also growing closer to Meera. A raven from Arya makes Bran take a look around and realizes the perils his family faces in these dark times. But through it all, Bran manages to find light and a reason to smile again.

Chapter Notes

Huge thanks to Justwanderingneverlost for the gorgeous mood board. Her first ever for Bran and Meera. :) Also, huge thanks to her for betaing this chapter.

Trying to get the timelines all in sync and I think I got it just about right.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

BRAN

Bran sat at the table of the main hall, Sansa to one side and Maester Wolkan to his other. Meera was close by as he could feel her presence, almost a distraction. How had he avoided this for so long? Why had he postponed his apology to her? She could have been here the whole time if he had just been able to put aside the Three-Eyed Raven!


But that was selfish. And a Lord has to be more than his own wants.


He listened to the complaints and requests, remembering years ago when he was seated at that very table and heard the requests of his countrymen. He missed Maester Luwin. He missed Ser Roddick. But more than anything he missed his mother, father, Robb, and Rickon. Rickon who he had sent off with Osha in hopes that he’d be safe. But the Starks had been betrayed, again.


“My Lord, we’re having an issue with bandits. They’ve depleted our food stores and taken our horse. It took me seven days to walk here to beg for your help. I left my two sons in charge of our household to come to you today. Please, help us.”


Bran nodded. “There are three men. They’ll continue to live off of you,” he confirmed. “We’ll send a few stout soldiers to put an end to the thieving. They are to be brought here alive to face justice.” He took a deep breath and glanced at Sansa. “In the meantime, you will be given a horse and food. I will give the soldiers the exact location of your criminals.”


The man stared at him dumbfounded. He lowered his head and with glistening eyes, holding in a sob, he thanked him. “Thank you, My Lord. My lady.”


He was the last one for the day and Sansa turned to him with a smile on her face. “You have a knack for this, Bran.”


“When Robb left, before Theon came and took Winterfell, Maester Luwin was teaching me.” He looked at his hands. “One of the Greyjoy men killed him. A knife to the gut before they burned the keep. We found him in the Godswood, just before he died.” He shook his head. “Theon still hopes we’ll let him live in the North.”


Sansa took a deep breath and grasped his hand. “The North is a very large place.”


Bran felt conflicted and confessed the other part he knew. “He wants to live here and raise Yara’s baby. Says he’ll never get to have a child. He wants a homestead.”


He looked up as he felt eyes on him and found Meera speaking to one of the Lords, but her eyes kept flicking to him.


“And you’re still against it?” Sansa asked.


“Shouldn’t I be?”


His sister tilted her head as she looked down at the papers on the table in front of her. “Perhaps. But I’m probably not the right person to ask.”


“How have you forgiven him?”


She blushed and Bran realized he stepped out of line as her eyes filled with tears. “He saved my life,” she said softly. “He fought against Ramsay’s control over him and helped me escape so Brienne could find me. Would have taken me to the Wall and suffered Jon’s wrath if he had to.” She looked at him. “All the bad things he did, betraying Robb, Ser Rodrik, the farm boys...that’s not who Theon is, now. He regrets his actions, doesn’t he?”


Bran nodded and looked at his fur covered lap. “He seems to.”


“I have no doubt Theon will live with a lifetime of regret. He and Robb were like brothers and he betrayed him. Betrayed all of us. I know that weighs on him. But in the end, he saved me. I suppose it might be selfish of me to want him to get what he wants, but I know the torture he endured at Ramsay’s hands.”


He took a deep breath. “I know. I saw what he endured.”


She squeezed his hand. “You’re so much stronger than I am. I don’t know that I could handle seeing all you have and still remained as close to you as you are.”


He shook his head. “I wonder sometimes if I’m enough of me.”


She smiled. “You’re still my little brother. Behind all the strange Three-Eyed Raven, you’re still Bran.” She stood. “And I’m not the only person who thinks so. Otherwise, she wouldn’t be here.”


With that, Sansa walked away, leaving him still seated at the table. The rest of the hall cleared out, leaving him alone with Meera and Podrick who remained by the door. “You’re good at this. Being a Lord. Running a Keep,” Meera commented.


Bran sighed. “I had a little training before we were driven from Winterfell. Sansa’s a good teacher as well.”


“Are you done for the day?” He nodded. “I had a surprise made for you if you’re willing.”


Bran smiled at her. “I am.”


“It’s outside.” She looked at Podrick. “Give me a few minutes to get it ready.”


“Of course, My Lady.”


Meera exited the hall and Podrick gave him a smile. “What?”


“You could easily look to see what it is.”


Bran nodded. “I could.”


“But you haven’t.”


“It ruins her surprise if I do.” Pod’s smile widened. “Why are you smiling like that?”


“You’ve changed since I’ve been here. It’s nice to see a more normal person,” he answered. But his eyes widened and he began to stumble over his words, “Not that you’re not normal, My Lord...”


Bran shook his head and waved him off. “I know what you meant. I suppose that when it comes to Meera, I want to be normal. A man who is trying to repair what I destroyed.”


Meera peeked into the hall and waved for Bran to be brought forward and Podrick rolled him out of the hall and to the new stone paths that had been constructed to accommodate his chair. Beside Meera was a horse with a specialized saddle. “I found some plans the other day. I had them altered to fit your height now and I think this should work...”


Bran smiled and nodded. “It’s brilliant.”


She blushed a little. “Well, if we get you saddled up, I’m sure we can get Podrick on a horse and we can go for a ride.”


He nodded and Podrick called for one of the larger guards to come help Bran into the saddle. His legs were fit into the stirrups and he was belted onto the saddled. “Gallop around so we can see how it works,” Meera suggested.


It had been years since he’d ridden a horse by himself. Robb had still been alive. Robb, Theon, his mother, he thought but remembered how to do it. He galloped slowly, able to guide the horse, not with his thighs and feet, but by leaning his body and using the reins. He came to a stop in front of Meera who had a smile on her face. She wasn’t someone who smiled often. She was rather dour, much like Jon. But she climbed onto the saddle of her horse, Podrick and Riff behind them on their own. Apparently, Meera had thought ahead. Bran led the way out of the castle as people looked on in shock to see the crippled Lord atop a horse.


Traveling out beyond Winterfell, light snow covering the ground, he could see first hand the true devastation the war had taken on his lands. The ground was still scorched and he pulled the horse to a stop and looked around. It was burnt almost as far as the eye could see. Meera spoke. “Things will grow, again.”


“You’re sure?”


She nodded. “Sometimes, when farming, people burn the ground to get it ready for fresh crops. This will all grow, again. You just need seed.”


He heaved a sigh. “The North has never been a place that can operate without the help of others. Some other Lords forget that. We depended on the other kingdoms for resources. It would be nice if we could become more self-sustaining, if for no other reason than to be able to care for our people in times when it’s hard for southron resources to get to us.” He could feel her looking at him, and the gaze felt like it was piercing through to his soul, weighing him. He wondered if she found him lacking. “What sort of seed?”


“What was here before?”


“Mostly grassland,” he answered.


“Parsnips grow in winter. Onions. Radishes,” she offered. “I’m sure some of your Lord’s have those and can share. There are people needing work. If Winterfell has farms to tend...”


He smiled at her and nodded. “I’ll send word to the other keeps when we get back. You’d make a fine Lady, as well.”


Meera’s cheeks brightened. “Come on, let’s see how you can handle that horse.”


*~*


Bran had sent off ravens as soon as they had returned and Meera had seen the horses back to the stable even when he said she didn’t have to. She had grown quiet, wanting races after he had complimented her, not words.


Sansa knocked and opened the door. “I saw you riding out of the castle,” she said with a bright smile. “Everything alright?”


He nodded. “Yes. I had control of the horse the whole time.” He tilted his head. “I also got to physically survey the damage the fire has done to our lands.


“It’s devastating,” she said as she looked down at her hands.


“It probably could be. But Meera gave me an idea about seeds. Farmers sometimes burn away the plants that are already there to get ready for the next crop. We have people looking for work all the time, perhaps if we had farms directly outside the keep...”


“Then not only do we have a sustainable source of food but a solution for people who want work and wage,” she said with a smile. “That’s brilliant.”


He nodded. “Meera even gave me a few ideas for plants that grow in winter...”


“Did she?” But something about her tone caused him to blush and then she chuckled. “You’re blushing, Bran.”


“Yes, I know. Stop.”


She shook her head, a smile still on her face. “No. Robb would come back and haunt me if I didn’t take the time to tease you. Besides, you’ve already admitted how you feel about her.”


He rolled his eyes and nodded. “Yes, I suppose I have.”


They were silent for a few moments before her voice echoed through the room. “How are Jon and Daenerys? And Arya?”


Bran let his eyes fall back, moving through space and found Jon and Daenerys’ armies stationed outside Harrenhal. The burnt castle had already seen a battle that day, and Jon was speaking with the queen and Jaime.


Jaime smiled at her pleased expression. “I’ll escort you back to your tent, Your Grace.”

“Thank you, Ser Jaime, but I’ll take her back,” Jon said as he joined them. “Well fought today.”

He smiled and nodded. “I wish I still had my hand if, for no other reason, than to see how good I would be against you.”

Daenerys looped her hand through Jon’s arm and nodded. “I’m sure that would have been a fight to see.”


Bran flashed back into the room with Sansa and heaved a sigh. “They took Harrenhal and the Lannister forces there. Jon and Daenerys are well. There was a minor skirmish, but that was handled by Jon and Jaime.”


“They’re both well?”


Bran nodded and looked at his hands. “They fought together.”


She gave a small smile. “Good. And Arya?”


He slipped out of the room again and into the void, moving over the land, searching for the call of Stark blood. He roamed through the castle and stopped at the chamber to the Lord’s room and entered it only to immediately wish he hadn’t. He opened his eyes, wide as he stared at Sansa.


“What? What’s wrong?” The panic in her voice was almost comical considering what he’d just seen. “Is Arya in danger?”


He shook his head and blushed. He could feel the heat in his cheek all the way to his ears. “She’s fine.”


Sansa looked at him for several long beats, and he found he couldn’t look at her. Her voice then sounded in the room. “What was she doing?”


His eyes flicked up to hers. “What does it matter?” he snapped.


Sansa bit her bottom lip and he could see she was stifling giggles. “I suppose next time you should learn how to knock.”


“How was I supposed to know that’s what they were doing!?”


“Was the door closed?” He nodded. “Did you hear anything before you went in?”


He hadn’t even hesitated before he had entered the room. “I don’t know.”


“I’ll wager that from now on, you’ll check,” she said as she stood and walked to the door, still grinning.


*~*


Bran leaned against the heart tree, his eyes closed as he surveyed the kingdom. Cersei was still locked in the keep, plotting the demise of Jon and Daenerys. Arya and Gendry were greeting their people and she helped him read at night. And Sansa was alone in her room, sleeping, a shirt balled into her hands. He sighed and shook his head, knowing that eventually, she would have to come to terms with it, but he wouldn’t be the one to confront her about it again. At least, not yet.


The crunch of snow brought him out of his vision and he looked up to see Meera, wrapped in a heavy cloak, much like his sister's, but the fur resembled that of Summer. Her request. “Sansa did a lovely job on your cloak.”


Meera looked down at it. “It feels a little too much,” she answered and came to kneel in front of him. She looked up at the red leaves of the tree and sighed. “You’re not worried, being here alone?”


He shook his head. “The only way in is through the gate, and Podrick and Riff are guarding it.”


She smiled. “They are. It’s how I knew where to find you.”


“Is something wrong?”


“Yes,” she said with a sigh. “What you said earlier, about me being a good Lady, you know that I’ve never wanted that, right?”


He nodded. “Yes. You wanted to protect your brother. And then you wanted to protect me.”


She nodded and looked at the snow on the ground. “I don’t know that I want to be a Lady. I don’t mind helping people if they need it, fighting for them, but running a keep, attending feasts, being nice to Lords and Ladies who don’t deserve respect feels to be more than I can handle.”


He took a deep breath, wanting to make her see that there was more to it than that. “Arya was exactly the same. She never wanted to be a Lady. Part of her still revolts against the idea, even though she’s with Gendry in Storm’s End.”


“But she’s still there.”


He nodded. “She went where he did because she loves him. She’s adaptable. She also realized that just because she was the Lady of the keep didn’t mean she had to stop being all the other things she was. She’s the one training their troops in combat, she’s overseeing teaching Gendry how to read and write. And she’s doing all this while also sitting at the head table, beside him, because she knows that’s where she belongs.”


“Is this where I belong?”


His heart began racing and he looked down at his hands. “I hope it is.”


“You have Sansa, here. She knows a great deal more about running a keep than I ever could...”


“Are you saying you want to leave?”


“No,” she quickly answered. “But I’m saying I don’t know that I can be the type of Lady that I hear the people talk about in reference to your mother.”


Bran nodded and sighed. “You’re nothing like my mother. And while I love her and miss her, I’m glad of that. I would never ask you to be something you aren’t, Meera. I asked you to come because I already know the woman you are and...I find it’s something I don’t want to live without.”


She blushed for a moment then leaned forward slowly. He thought he might explode from the anticipation of her kiss. He met her half-way, his hands shaking, his mind whirling. She kissed him and it filled him up with happiness in a way he hadn’t felt since before his accident. She pulled away far too soon, and he took several deep breaths but found nothing was enough to make him breathe normally.


She peered at him nervously, and he worried that she would regret her decision and reached out a hand to take hers. “I’m scared of this, Bran. How I feel for you is different and I don’t know...”


“Meera, I’m not asking you for anything but a chance. You’re still free to leave and return home.”


He would lament it for the rest of his days if that happened. He wanted her to stay with him forever, to let him love her the way she deserved. He wanted more rides through the forests, archery lessons, and late-night meetings in the Godswood.


“I don’t want to leave. I’m simply afraid of staying.”


“Is there anything I could do or say to ease your worries?”


She gave him a smile. “No. And I’m not leaving, Bran. I simply wanted you to know my mind.”


He took her gloved hand in his and brought it up to his lips and kissed the back of it. “I’ll tell you that I haven’t truly been this happy in years. Since before my father left for King’s Landing. I owe that to you.”


She took her hand back from him and stood. “I’ll get Podrick to help you back into the keep. Your hands are so cold I can feel them through my gloves.”


She started to walk away and his voice stopped her. “Will you come back with him? Escort me back to the castle?”


Her smile was a beautiful thing as she nodded.


*~*


Bran sat alone in his solar, still thinking about the kiss. It stirred him, even gave him feverish dreams about what more could happen, what it would feel like to touch her. But then worry and doubt cluttered his mind. How could he possibly please her as a cripple? He put his head in his hands, knowing that things between them would be different than other couples. There would be...limitations.


“Podrick,” he called and his guard opened the door. “Please come in and shut the door.”


The man did as requested. He wasn’t much older than him, but as he was the closest male to him at the castle, and he knew Podrick would keep silent, he felt like he was his only source to ask. There was no way he would ask Tormund. The Wildling would make the situation more embarrassing than it already was. His sister was out of the question. But as he stared at the man in front of him, he felt doubt creeping in once again. He fought it off, for his own sake.


“I’ve reached a problem in which I think you might be able to help me.”


Podrick nodded. “Whatever you need, My Lord.”


“Have a seat,” he said as he exhaled a breath. “A few days ago...Meera and I kissed.” The smile on Pod’s face looked genuine and he was thankful to feel like he had someone cheering for him. However, he said nothing. “You see, I was worried before that...I wouldn’t be able to...because of my paralysis...”


Podrick’s face registered recognition. “That’s no longer a concern, My Lord?”


He shook his head. “No. As of the last few days, I have no concerns in that area. What I do worry about is...having never done...I mean to say, you know I can watch things, not that I’m watching that but...I don’t know how to say what I want to say.” He let out a heavy sigh, pausing and looking at the desk.


Luckily, Podrick understood. “My Lord, in my experience, women are difficult to please and each one is different.”


“Yes, I understand, but I want to know how you knew what to do. I know of Tyrion’s gift to you after Blackwater. They wouldn’t take your money. How did you know what to do?”


Podrick twirled his thumbs and looked at his hands then up at Bran. “I didn’t, really. I followed the sounds they made. The way they...moved when I touched them in a certain manner.” He shrugged and sighed. “I took my time and they liked what I did.”


Bran put his head in his hands and looked up at Podrick. “And it was instinct?”


He nodded. “Mostly, yes. It-it was my first time, My Lord. I was nervous and afraid.” He hung his head. “The last thing you want is to be a disappointment.”


Bran heaved a sigh and nodded. “Thank you, Podrick.”


“You’re welcome, My Lord.” He stood and walked to the door and stopped. “My Lord?”


“Yes?”


“I think it’s different, better, when it’s someone you love. At least, I hope it is.”


Bran gave him a nod and he left soon after.


*~*


He raced through the woods, trying to keep up with Meera as her horse was clearly in the lead.

He could only hear the sound of her laughter over that of the horses. As he reached the clearing, Winterfell looming on the horizon, he came to a stop beside her and let Podrick and Riff catch up.


She looked at him, her cheeks pink, a smile on her face, her hair tousled by the wind and he thought she was beautiful. “Lost again, Lord Stark. If I didn’t know better I would think you liked losing.”


He shook his head. “There’s only one thing worse than a sore loser. A bad winner,” he mocked.


“And only sore losers say that,” she joked. Podrick and Riff joined them and they made their way slowly back to Winterfell, Riff in front and Podrick behind them. “Before Robb left, he was showing me how to shoot while on horseback. I think, once I’ve gotten a better handle on this, I’d like to try that again.”


She smiled. “I think you’ve had plenty of time in the saddle. Two weeks is long enough. We can set it up along the trails. Put out some targets if you don’t want others watching.”


Bran nodded. “Good idea. I feel like I have enough people watching my every move as it is.” He looked over at her and tilted his head. “Do you like Winterfell?”


She nodded. “It’s better than being beyond the Wall.”


“That’s not saying much, though,” Bran replied.


Meera looked over at him and gave him a small smile. “It’s cold, but then I feel like that’s something I’ve grown used to. But inside is warm and inviting. Your sister is very nice. And you’re here.”


“That’s a good thing, right?”  


She nodded. “It’s what made me come back.”


As they came through the gates Maester Wolkan and Sansa met them at the entrance to the great hall. “Arya has sent a raven,” she said softly. Bran was helped back into his chair and took the scroll from Sansa. He blushed as he read the part about Meera but then looked at Sansa. “I need the Godswood.”


“Is she alright?”


“Someone is sneaking into their chambers. They want to know who. It’s easier for me to see from the wood.”


Sansa and Meera followed Podrick as he pushed Bran’s chair to the Godswood. Meera and Pod worked together to settle him at the base of the tree. He put his hand to the bark and felt his mind race through the world and land in Storm’s End. And there she was, Melisandre. She opened the door and strode inside. She passed by anything belonging to Arya, but moved Gendry’s items, in no hurry. When she finished, she left the room and returned to her chambers where she removed the amulet that had been glowing at her throat. Her appearance transformed, revealing her to be an old crone. He watched as she went into the keep, glaring at his sister but smiling at Gendry. She dropped some firewood in front of the new Lord and he helped her gather it.


When he came out of the vision, he looked up at Sansa gravely. “What? Who is it?” she asked.


“Melisandre.”


She tilted her head. “Jon’s red witch?”


Bran nodded. “She actually knew Arya and Gendry before she ever met Jon. She tried to kill Gendry but Davos made Stannis reconsider and they only used his blood. She’s on Arya’s list.”


“What about Jon and Daenerys?”


He nodded and touched the tree again. Wildfire greeted him as he found Daenerys, scraping and clawing her way out of the ravine. He wanted to help her, he wanted to extend his hands and pull her out, as she cried. He could see the flames licking over her body and it physically hurt him to see his brother being held to the ground by Jaime, Tyrion on his knees beside him, and Davos crying silent tears. They all thought she was dead. She was bleeding, crying, naked, and on fire but she was alive. When she finally got to solid ground she stood and walked out of the Wildfire toward Jon who scrambled to get close to her. He was held back by Jaime and Davos. She went into the water and Jon was with her, only steps behind. Bran stood amazed to see the water boil as she walked into it then she sank beneath the surface. Her hair was gone, but she was alive. Jon seemed on the verge of panic but held it together well.


Even between the branches, he could see the Red Keep. He cast his mind inside and watched as Cersei sat at the balcony, drank her wine, and smiled to watch it all burn. She thought she had won. He felt a great sense of smug satisfaction to know that she was grossly mistaken. He left the Red Keep and returned back to his own body. Meera was sitting beside him as Sansa sat across from her. Podrick, Brienne, and Tormund were now all looking at him as well.


“Cersei blew up an inn with Wildfire. Daenerys was inside.” Sansa gasped, her hands over her mouth. “But Daenerys lived. She’s alright.”


Tormund took a deep breath. “And your brother.”


“He’s panicked about her. Jaime kept him from walking into the fire.”


Meera frowned and looked at Sansa. “Jaime...is the one that you—“


“That’s the past,” Sansa interjected quickly. “But they’re alright?”


Bran nodded. “Get me inside so I can write to Arya.”


*~*


He was seated on the edge of his bed as he stared into the fire. Watching Jon struggle to get to the woman he loved brought home the realization that he would probably never be able to defend Meera. Fighting for her, from his side, would look incredibly different. He felt unworthy and despair was beginning to settle in his heart.


Was he wasting his time? Would she be able to love him?


A knock sounded at the door and he bid the person to enter. It was as if his very thoughts had caused her to appear. “I know it’s late,” she said softly, “but I wanted to see how you were doing after all that you saw today.”


He sat up straight and folded his hands on his lap. “I’m alright. Worried about my family. Even Sansa. Cersei has offered a Lordship and a castle to the person who kills her and brings her head to her.” He ran a hand down his face. “None of them are safe and I feel powerless to help.”


Meera shook her head and pulled a chair to sit in front of him. “You’re not powerless. You’re not,” she reaffirmed. “You’re the Three-Eyed Raven. You can see everything that’s happening. You sent the raven to tell Arya about the threat to her...”


“But I didn’t warn Jon.”


“You did that before they left, right? You told them about the Wildfire under King's Landing. You told them that Cersei lied about being pregnant. You’ve already helped them.”


He tilted his head as he looked at her. “It’s hard to watch my family continue to suffer after all they’ve been through. I want peace for them.”


“And for you.”


He nodded finally. “And for me.” He took a deep breath and cautiously reached for her hand. “And peace for me is you. It has been for a long time. You’re the one bright spot in all the horror I see. Even when I look at my family, I see their pain. I see all the horrors that happened to them. But when I look at you, there’s light and happiness, even after all we suffered together.”


She squeezed his hand and smiled. “I wondered for a while if coming back was a mistake. But I’m glad I did. I realized that I had missed you.”


He took a deep breath. “I want to spend my life trying to make you as happy as you make me. You made me feel, again. It would be my honor and privilege if you would marry me.”


She bit her lip and squeezed his fingers. “I won’t be a Lady like your sister.”


He smiled. “I want you, Meera.”


She smiled back at him and nodded. “Yes. My answer is yes,” she said before she leaned forward and kissed him. He cupped her face in his hands and couldn’t help but smile against her lips.

Chapter End Notes

Happy New Year! I hope to at least get out a chapter a week until this story is finished. My plan is to be done by the time the new season starts. I have loved taking this journey with all of you and I hope that you have all enjoyed reading. I also hope that you continue to enjoy this fic until the very end.

Sansa XIV

Chapter Summary

Sansa learns of Bran and Meera’s engagement and they all get devastating news from King’s Landing and Storm’s End.

Chapter Notes

Really making headway. Hope to have it complete by premiere date.

Thanks gonto justwanderingneverlost for the mood board and the beta job for this chapter.

SANSA


Ocean, as far as she could see. The balcony, with its white stone and ivy climbing up the sides was as familiar to her as Winterfell. The sound of a babe crying turned her attention from the waves and she entered the room to find the child inside its cradle, squirming.


On instinct she lifted the baby from the crib, and bounced him. She didn’t know how she knew it was a boy or even that he was hungry and it was her own breast that would feed him, but she walked back to the terrace and sat in the sunlight. She undid the stays and soon the child was suckling away and a smile spread across her face.


He was beautiful. Chubby cheeks, a small wisp of red hair, little fingers clutching hers. She hummed in contentment, feeling safe and at home. She smiled as familiar fingers traced over her cheek. The masculine form moved around her chair to kneel beside her. But just as his face came into view, the baby cried and she turned away to soothe him. How she hated to hear him cry.


When she turned back to the man at her side he was no longer kneeling beside her, and the baby had disappeared from her arms. She searched frantically, a sudden hysteria and pain coursing through her only to find the man laying on floor in a pool of blood. It was Jaime.


She went to her knees beside him, now in a darkened room. She didn’t know where the blood was coming from or how to help him, only that she was helpless to stop it.


Her heart ached as she cried and held him in her arms. Her fingers brushed over his face as his green eyes stared lifelessly at the ceiling.


She awoke in a cold sweat, feeling it at the nape of her neck and drifting down her spine. Her hands shook as she felt fear tracking through her body. She sat in her bed, staring at the fire which had nearly died and weeped.


Her heart ached with missing him. She thought she could do it, could be strong and move on, but it had been harder than she could ever imagine. She finally wiped the tears from her cheeks and lay back on her pillows, pulling the shirt buried beneath them to her face, inhaling the small but lingering scent of him. Soon, it would be gone, and then she would have nothing but memories.


*~*


Her sword slashed through the air with ferocity and she thumped Podrick on the side of the head with the blunted practice blade. “Ow!”


“My Lady!” Brienne chided. “This is practice.” She turned to Podrick. “And you need to learn to keep your guard up,” she chastised.  


Sansa turned away from Podrick, knowing he was innocent and had done nothing to deserve that. But she was angry, and if she couldn't get it out with a sword in her hand, she didn’t know when the proper time would be.


Brienne stepped close. “My Lady, are you alright?”

She took a deep breath and shook her head ever so slightly. “Podrick, I’m going to walk Lady Sansa to her room. You should find Lord Bran.”


He gave a nod and walked away still rubbing his head. They walked in silence through the castle and once inside her room, Sansa slumped onto her bed and folded her arms over her chest. “I didn’t mean to hurt Pod.”


Brienne nodded. “I’m certain he knows that. What is the matter? You know you can tell me anything and I will keep your faith.”


Sansa ran a hand over her face and looked at her loyal guard and friend. “I had a nightmare that’s left me shaken. It started with this baby, a sweet baby boy that I think was mine. And then his father arrived and before I could see his face, the baby cried again and when...when I turned back, we were in a dark room. It looked like...the Red Keep. And Jaime was laying on the floor in a pool of blood...and he was dead,” she whispered the last part.


Brienne stepped forward and put a calming hand on her shoulder. “Ser Jaime is alive. Your brother saw him in his vision only yesterday.”


She nodded. “I know.” She stared at her hands as she willed away the tears. “But it felt so real. All of it,” she whispered. “The baby, my happiness, and then the grief,” she shook her head, “I know I’ll eventually marry someone and have a child, but even though it wasn’t real, I still lament the loss of that child. It could have been ours. Mine and Jaime’s. We could have been together and happy...”


“And that’s not an option?”


“It doesn’t appear to be. My duty is to my family and the North. There is no scenario where I remain wardeness of the North and I get to be with Jaime. That’s...”


“That’s why you told him it was over.” Brienne pulled the chair from the table over to sit in front of Sansa. “I understand about duty, my Lady. My duty is to you, but that doesn’t mean I can’t still have the things I want. Because of you, I have been given the position of your protector, but that’s afforded me other opportunities. I didn’t foresee Tormund, because who in their right mind would conjure up such a man,” she said with a roll of her eyes, “but he’s mine just the same. And you allowed that to flourish as not many would. You gave me the chance for happiness in a way I never expected or intended, because you would not stand in the way of what could make me happy, even as I am someone who serves you.” She took a deep breath. “You’ve given a great deal for this country and your family. When you told me of your abuse, I didn’t feel pity but admiration. You are one of the strongest women I’ve ever met and it is an honor to be at your side as you continue to provide better lives for people. But what does that mean if you give up your happiness?”


Sansa shook her head. “He hurt Bran when he was a child. Bran allowed him to live, initially, because being able to fight against the White Walkers was an advantage that only Jaime had. Now that it’s over and he’s more Bran than Three-Eyed Raven, he doesn’t want him here and believes I can do better.”


Brienne frowned. “What do you believe, my Lady?”


She shook her head as tears slipped down her face. “I believe that I was happy for a very short time. That my worry was boiled down to who would find us kissing in the Godswood or me sneaking from his room at dawn,” she said, blush coloring her cheeks. “I put off all thoughts of him leaving or that others would take issue with us being together because when I was with him...I didn’t care about any of it.”


“Perhaps you still shouldn’t.”


“Bran will kill him if he comes North.”


Brienne eyed her for a moment. “Then, my Lady, perhaps it's time you considered if you would mind living in the South.”


“I can’t. Bran needs me here.”


She tilted her head. “Does he? Truly?” Sansa nodded, though she was unsure. “You’re a good sister and a good lady. I only hope people appreciate all you’ve given up for the good of others.”


Sansa gave her a sad smile. “Thank you.”


She stood and put the chair back at the table. “Change clothes, my Lady, and I’ll escort you to the main hall to break your fast.”


Sansa wiped at her face again. “Yes, very good.”


*~*


She entered Bran’s solar and found her brother seated at the desk with Meera, both reading over some text in a book. She felt out of place, as if she was intruding. She cleared her throat and they both looked up, Meera standing and bowing her head. Sansa gave her a smile. “I told you, if I’m  not allowed to call you Lady Meera then you’re not allowed to bow your head to me.”


The other girl smiled. “A fair trade.”


Bran smiled at Sansa. “I have news.”


“Oh? More visions? News from the south?”


He shook his head. “No, from here. I’ve asked Meera to be my wife and she accepted.”


Sansa smiled and rounded the table to hug her brother, laughing as she wrapped her arms around him. “This is wonderful!” She hugged Meera as well who accepted it with a laugh of her own. “So very wonderful!”


“I would ask you, my Lady, to help me with the details of the wedding. We would like to do an Old Gods ceremony, as so much of our time together was spent beneath a Heart tree.”


Sansa nodded and took both of their hands. “I would be honored! Would you like me to make a dress for you?”


At that Meera blanched. “I...I don’t know. I haven’t really been one to wear dresses.”


Sansa put a hand on her arm. “Arya wasn’t one to wear dresses, either but I made her one she actually liked.”


Meera gave her a shy smile. “Then I welcome your attempts, my Lady.”


“Sansa. You’ll be my sister. Please, call me Sansa.”


“Meera.”


Sansa looked at Bran. “When would you like this wedding to happen?”


“Two moons? That should give the courier time to get to your father, shouldn’t it?” he asked Meera.


“If the courier doesn’t meet him on the road,” she said with a smile. “I am interested in the two of you meeting.”


Sansa took a deep breath. “Two moons. We can work with that. Perhaps Arya could make the trip back. Or Jon.”


Bran rubbed a hand over his chin. “That would be near to the twins being born. But we could send word to Arya. I’ll draft a letter,” he said softly.


“And I’ll have my things moved into Robb’s old room and you two will take the Lord and Lady’s chamber.”


“There’s no need in that, Sansa,” Bran said with a shake of his head.


“Yes, there is. You’re ruling this keep. Yes, you have some help, but you’re doing it. Take it. Besides,” she said as she walked toward the door, “the bed’s bigger.” She gave them both a wink, laughing as their blushes.


*~*


She had several different fabrics brought to her, Brienne and Meera standing with her. It was nearly dusk but she wanted Meera to select the fabric that would make up her dress. They were all a variation of white.


Meera was looking perplexed. “I don’t know which to choose.”


Sansa smiled. “Touch them. Feel them on your skin. Which do you think would be more comfortable?”


Meera stepped forward and ran her hand over the different fabrics but came back to the silk in the middle, her hand drifting over it again. “This feels nice.”


Sansa smiled at her. “That would’ve been my choice, too,” she said, hoping her words were encouraging. “Would you mind if we got some measurements?” Sansa opened the door and her handmaiden entered.


Meera nodded and moved behind the screen and the handmaiden followed. Meera’s heavy layers came off and were draped over the top of the changing screen. Sansa sat at her table, a piece of parchment in front of her as her handmaiden called out the measurements to her and she wrote them down.


When she was done, Meera redressed and Sansa had her handmaiden collect the fabrics and store the ones they weren’t going to use. “Sansa, can I speak to you? Privately?” Meera asked.


She nodded and Brienne gave a nod and stood outside the door, closing it behind her. Sansa still sat at her table and Meera sat in front her. She kept her hands in her lap and her eyes on the wood. “Is everything alright?”


Meera nodded and sighed. “It’s...you’re very good at being the Lady of Winterfell. I was wondering if you would show me some of what you do?”


Sansa nodded. “I would be happy to.” She wondered if this would give cause for others to push for her to marry. She wouldn't consider it until Bran was married and settled with Meera, though she didn’t think that would take long. “Is there anything in particular you’re curious to learn? We can start there.”


Meera frowned. “How do you know what will be best for people? How do you not give in to every story you hear?”


Sansa thought on it for a moment. “ I suppose I simply think of what they need in that situation and would it harm anyone else to give it to them.” She leaned her arms on the table and looked at Meera. “My father was a fair and honorable man, and his goal was to make sure the people that he protected didn’t suffer under him but that they knew they could come to him with problems. I think the key is to always listen and make sure they understand that you hear them. Even if you can’t do anything to make their problem better, then they can know that you listen and care. With smaller problems, that’s sometimes enough.”


Meera nodded. “That makes sense. I’m sure I was supposed to learn these things with my father before my brother and I decided we had to leave.”


“You saved Bran’s life on more than one occasion. I’m very glad he had you.”


Meera’s eyes drifted to the fire. “Rickon was with us for a time, but Bran thought it would be safer to send him to one of your allies with Osha. I’m sorry for what happened to him. He was a good boy.”


Sansa looked down at her hands, barely even remembering what Rickon looked like as a boy. “Those that hurt Rickon paid for their crimes. I fed Ramsay to his dogs.”


“He was your husband?” Meera squeaked.


“He was my torturer by marriage,” she answered, not wanting to discuss Ramsay and his evil ways. He made her stomach turn and her insides quiver in fear. She shouldn’t still be feeling that way after all these years. She shouldn’t still fear him even if he was a ghost. “But he’s dead. Gone and forgotten.”


Meera hesitated a moment and frowned. “Not by you, though.”


“I do my best and hardly think of him most days.”


“You were married twice, though?”


She nodded. “My first husband, Tyrion Lannister, was very different from Ramsay. He was kind to me, always quick with a joke. He was there by my side when I got word of Robb and my mother. He tried to help me, but...” she shook her head. “I couldn’t accept help from a Lannister. Not at that point.”


Meera took a deep breath. “Bran told me what Jaime did to him.” Sansa looked up at her abruptly. “You love a man who did that to your family?”


She shook her head and swallowed thickly. “I hate what he did to Bran. But Jaime is not the same man as he was when he did that. Brienne was the first to tell me that. Tyrion the second. And I actually spent time with him, got to know him, and I realized that there was someone who I could care for hidden in there.”


“Do you think he’s sorry for what he did to Bran?”


She nodded emphatically. “I know he is. I think, at the time, he was only worried about saving his life and his sister’s. He was labeled the Kingslayer, but that act came out of desperation because the Mad King was going to blow up King’s Landing. Jaime killed him to keep it from happening.” She hung her head. “If there is one thing I’ve learned in life it’s that most people are capable of change. We simply have to give them the opportunity. Jaime took his first step when he rode North after his sister said she wasn’t going to send her forces. Even then, when he arrived, I wanted his head for what he’d done to my brother.”


“But, now, you love him?”


“That’s not a word that I’ve been willing to use for what I feel for Jaime.”


“Why not?”


“Because if I say it out loud and I don’t get to be with him ever again, I can’t wallow in that. I have to look at it as something that happened and I can move on from him,” she answered with a shaky breath.


“And if he rode North today?”


“I’d be furious he left my brother when they needed him.”


Meera rolled her eyes. “You know what I mean. If he was to come North, for you, would you be with him?”


She bit her lip and sighed. “Bran wouldn’t allow him in the North. He’s made that rather clear, not that I blame him. But if Jaime wanted me, was able to have a future with me, I would have to seriously consider it.”


“Because you do love him.”


Sansa took a deep breath. “I’ll put it this way. I’ve had very little happiness since I left King’s Landing. But when I was with him, sometimes arguing, I felt it. He made me happy.”

Meera looked at the table, a faint blush covering her cheeks. “Bran says I make him happy, and I know he makes me happy. Perhaps not all is lost.”


She shook her head. “It’s easier for me to acknowledge that it’s over and move on, though I’m not ready to be someone’s wife.”


Meera smiled. “I hope you intend to stay for a while.”


She nodded and sighed. “As long as I can,” she replied.


*~*


Sansa was alone in her solar, lost in her thoughts about Brienne’s words. Would Jaime even want her? She sent him away and told him it was for good. Would he want her after she had done that?


A knock sounded at her door and she looked up to find Brienne and Riff. “Your brother has asked for you, my Lady. He’s in the Godswood.”


Sansa grabbed her cloak and pulled it over her shoulders as she followed Riff, Brienne behind her. When they reached Bran, Podrick and Meera were standing near him, each of them wore grave expressions.


“Jon and Daenerys have taken King’s Landing,” he said firmly, though he was looking at the snow. She could sense there was more, but she feared hearing it. “Cersei is dead. So is Tyrion.”


Sansa put her hands over her mouth, shock moving through her system. Brienne was the first to speak. “How?”


“Tyrion snuck into the castle with his crossbow. He heard Jaime and Cersei arguing and came in, intending to kill her so Jaime didn’t have to. Cersei...stabbed Jaime.” It was Brienne’s arms that held her up as she fell to her knees. “And she turned and killed Tyrion. Jaime killed Cersei.” Tears rolled down her cheeks but she felt hollow, as if Bran's words had scooped her insides out. “Jaime is alive, but he’s lost a lot of blood. Dany has been moved to a room to rest as she was experiencing cramps from the stress of losing Tyrion.”


Sansa looked at Brienne. “My dream.”


Brienne shook her head. “A coincidence.”


“I’m sorry, Sansa. I know you were close with Tyrion...” Bran said softly


“He was always kind to me. Teased me when we reunited, calling me wife...” she shook her head, more tears rolling down her face for her lost friend. “Is Dany alright?”


“As long as she rests. She’s only a few days removed from the inn blowing up. Her midwife and Sam are worried the constant trauma both mentally and physically could cause the babes to come early.”


She took a deep breath. “And Jaime?”


“He’s alive and being tended by Sam.” He sighed. “But that’s not all that happened today.”


“What? What else?”


“Two faceless men got into Storm’s End and were going to poison Arya. Melisandre revealed herself to Gendry and told him before it could happen, but when one of them was cornered, she ran. Arya and Gendry killed her but...Gendry was stabbed three times with a poisoned blade by the other.” He took a moment to let it sink in. “Arya told the Maester that he either saved Gendry’s life or she would kill him.”


Sansa gripped Brienne’s hand. “And?”


“He’s alive. The Maester knew the poison and provided the antidote. Arya is with him and hasn’t left his side.”


She couldn’t imagine what Arya was dealing with in that moment. Sansa looked at her brother, his expression sad as Meera held his hand. “Faceless Men don’t just go after you because of their own whims. They’re hired. Given a name, as Arya explained.”


Bran’s eyes went white as he placed his hand on the tree. Sansa looked at her faithful guard and frowned. “Jaime...”


“We’ll talk in your room,” she confirmed.


When Bran came out of his vision his face was angry. “We need a raven sent to Storm’s End. I know who hired them. We need to act fast. Arya isn’t their target.”


“Gendry...”


“More here than meets the eye,” Bran said. “But I’ll do whatever I can to get the message to Arya. If I have to warg the raven to ensure she gets it, I will.” He said, reaching for her hand. “I’ll do everything I can to keep her safe. Gendry, too.”


“What about King’s Landing? Jon? Daenerys? The babies?”


“Ser Jaime?” Brienne asked. Sansa was thankful for her.


“Jon and Dany are mourning and Jaime is still unconscious.” He lowered his head. “You should know her intent wasn’t to kill Jaime at that point. She was going to keep him until someone brought her your head and force him to look at it. That appeared to be the catalyst to make him act. That’s when he strangled Cersei.”


Sansa’s fingers tightened around Brienne’s. “Is there anyone coming for me?”


Bran frowned. “I don’t know. I can only look here in the castle. Find them before they can act.”


“We would need them to act before we would be able to deal with them, though,” Sansa responded. “I’ll compose a letter offering our condolences to Jon and Daenerys about Tyrion.”


“One to Jaime, as well,” Meera stated and everyone looked at her in confusion. “We’ve all lost brothers. Some of us live with the guilt of feeling like we could have done more to protect them. Whatever his crimes, Tyrion was his brother, and he loved him, right?” Sansa nodded. “Then one to Jaime.”  She felt a swell of affection toward her future sister and knew at that moment she would do everything she could to make her the best lady of a keep she could.


Meera stood. “Let’s get you back inside so you can send a raven to Storm’s End,” she said to Bran.


Sansa and Brienne watched them go and once they were out of sight, she turned to her guard and friend, tears still in her eyes. “I dreamed it. I dreamed him laying in a pool of blood where he’d been stabbed...” she cried. “I saw him...”


“My Lady,” she whispered. “Then, if that part came true...”


She shook her head. “I’m still Wardeness of the North.”


“Your brother is engaged to be married. And he will be in two moons. If you chose, you could go south.” Brienne stood and helped her to her feet. “You don’t have to make any decisions today.”


“I want him to ask me,” she whispered.


Brienne nodded. “I understand. Let’s get you inside.”


*~*


“Lord Tyrion never touched me,” she told Brienne as she came out from behind the changing screen in her gown. “On our wedding night, he told me he couldn’t do it and wouldn’t until I asked him.” She sat on the edge of the bed and hung her head. “I asked him what if I never asked. He just looked at me and said ‘ and so my watch begins ’.” She sniffed back tears. “He was a good man and I treated him terribly.”


Brienne sat in the chair at her table. “Those were different times, a different circumstance. When you reunited here, your relationship was different.”


She smiled and nodded. “It was. We were able to be friends, or something close to that. When he left he teased and called me wife , I called him husband .” She shook her head. “I can’t believe he’s gone,” she said. “He was the smartest person I knew and he was going to help Jon and Daenerys make this world better and now he’s gone.”


Brienne frowned. “I trust the king and queen to still achieve that without him by their side. It might be more difficult, but I have faith in them.”


She nodded. “I do as well. And then Arya and Gendry on top of all this. She wasn’t even their intended target.”


“Your brother will sort it out for them. He’ll get word to Arya in time and save them both. If there is one thing I learned from watching them when she was injured it’s that they’re fighters. They don’t know how to quit and they certainly won’t give up on one another.” Brienne’s reassuring words went far to ease Sansa's upset, though she worried for her family. She mourned Tyrion. She hated Cersei. And she...feared for Jaime.


With Tyrion gone, in the manner in which he passed, she knew he probably blamed himself. He loved his brother even if he hated that he killed their father. She pondered on that. She felt the same about what Jaime had done to Bran, but knew he was a different man now. One she missed. The casual ways he would find to touch her while she trained with her sword. Whispered in her ear as if he was giving her direction but was instead telling her how the world would envy him because she was his.


She was no longer a girl and should be over the idea of pretty words and a handsome man saying them, but when it came to him, she felt like that foolish girl who told her mother how handsome the prince was. Though, he ended up being a complete monster. Tyrion had saved her from him.


Tyrion, her friend, her former protector, was gone. There would be no more quips, no more need for wine, no more jokes about wine. There was an emptiness inside her where her friendship with Tyrion existed now. He was gone, killed by a hateful bitch that didn’t deserve Jaime or Tyrion. She swiped at her eyes and Brienne took her hand.


“Thank you, Brienne, for all you’ve done for me,” she said finally. She looked up at her guard who looked surprised but Sansa continued on, “I don’t feel I tell you that enough. I’m so happy and relieved to have you at my side. I never doubt whether you will be there for me, as both a protector and a friend. So, thank you.”


“My Lady, it is my honor to serve as your sworn sword, and I will do so with honor until the end of my days.”


She smiled and nodded. “To bed with you. I’ve kept you from Tormund and the girls for long enough.”


“Are you going to be alright?”


She nodded. “Yes. I will be.”


Brienne gave one last squeeze to her hand and left. Sansa looked down at her hands and no longer withheld the tears. She reached beneath the pillows and found Jaime’s tunic and held it to her face as she cried. She turned on her side, holding it against her cheek, wishing she was in King's Landing to take care of him. To see Tyrion one last time. To look after Daenerys and the babies.


She could do none of that, though. She was in Winterfell, for the foreseeable future. And then she would marry a lord, probably one from one of the larger Northron houses, and that thought made her physically ache.


But Bran hadn’t told her he was ready to rule alone, and until he did, she would stand at his side.

Gendry XIV

Chapter Summary

Gendry is feeling better. Lord Selwyn announces his departure for Winterfell. A letter from Bran shines a light on their most recent problem and a traitor is revealed.

Chapter Notes

thank you to justwanderingneverlost for the gorgeous mood board and for the beta on this chapter.

I know I said Meera was next, but after looking at my timeline, it had to be Gendry. Meera will def be the next chapter.

 

GENDRY

He opened one bleary eye followed by the other. The candles had dropped low, their light dim. He tried to move his fingers, relief flooding him as both fingers and hand moved when ordered. Looking down at them, he was still able to see the black tendrils of poison beneath his skin. He wondered how long they would last.

 

He rolled to his side to find Arya cuddle against him. “You awake?” he mumbled.

 

She shook her head and moved closer to him. “No.” He lifted his bad arm and traced his fingers over her face. She blinked her eyes open and stared at him, then took his hand in hers and smiled. “Does it hurt?”

 

He shook his head. “There's still some numbness in my elbow, but other than that, I’m alright.”

 

“And the wounds on your side?”

 

“They hurt, but I’ll live.”

 

She pressed her lips to his. “Yes, you will.”

 

“You saved my life,” he whispered into her hair.

 

“We’re even, now,” she returned, leaning up on her elbow and tracing her fingers over the black lines down his arm. She swallowed hard. “I don’t know what I would do without you, Gendry. It’s why I came with you. I couldn’t live with myself if you got hurt and I could have been here to stop it. Or worse, they killed you.”

 

He grabbed her hand and squeezed it. “But we did stop it. The maester had the antidote and I’m doing better. I wish we knew who hired them.”

 

She snuggled closer to him. “So do I.”

 

“I had a dream while I was under. About you and I.”

 

She pressed her lips against his throat. “What were we doing?”

 

He smiled, the picture still clear in his mind. “You had put our son on the floor to show me he could walk. And when you stood, you had another baby in your belly.”

 

She lifted her head and looked at him, her grey eyes wide. “Oh?”

 

He nodded, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear. “You were beautiful and grumpy,” he said with a chuckle. “But, you kept rubbing your hands over your belly and our son snuggled in my arms. That dream… that’s what made me come back. It’s what made me open my eyes because I wanted that to be our reality. And it never would be if I didn't wake up.”

 

She dropped her eyes to his chest, her brow wrinkled with worry. “I don’t know that I’d be a good mother.”

 

He ran his fingers over her cheek. “I happen to think you’d be wonderful. You take care of those you love. But it’s up to you. You know I won't ask you to do something you don't want.”

 

She leaned down and kissed him. “I love you. I love your faith in me, too.”

 

He pressed his lips to her brow, squeezing her tighter to him. “Arya?”

 

“Hmm?”

 

“Will you marry me?”

 

She tensed in his arms, but lifted her head to look at him, her bottom lip tucked between her teeth. She smoothed her fingers over his jaw and he thought his heart might beat out of his chest. The longer she took to answer, the more worried he became that she would refuse. She finally sighed. “Are you sure?”

 

He nodded. “You’re what I want. My future is you.”

 

She huffed out a sigh and smiled. “My future is you, too. Yes, I’ll marry you,” she whispered and pressed her lips to his and his heart soared with happiness. She pulled back, her lips turned down in a pout. “It’s too bad you’re injured or we could properly celebrate.”

 

He chuckled. “I’m all stitched up. Come on, my she-wolf, don’t tell me you’re afraid.”

 

She smirked. “Nice try. I seem to remember you denying me over and over again when I was injured.”

 

“To be fair, one of the injuries was to your leg,” he reminded and slid his hand over her thigh, knowing without looking where the blade had gone in. She still bore a scar from it.

 

She cupped his face in her hands and kissed him, gently at first, but the longer the kiss went on, the more frantic it became. She moaned against his lips and he guided her to straddle him. She sat up and grinned down at him before she pulled her tunic over her head. “It has been a week...”

 

He slid his hand over her body and cupped her breast, tweaking the hardened peak, and she bucked against him. Her fingers worked diligently and untied his pants, freeing his cock. He dropped his head back to the pillow and closed his eyes while she stroked over his heated flesh. He was unsure if he could watch her and not turn into a greenboy unused to the touch of a woman.

 

She shifted on the bed and his eyes flew open as she slid his cock inside her mouth. He relaxed against the pillows again and carded his fingers through her hair. She was going to be his wife. He felt such a swelling of love for her at that moment, he reached down and pulled her up to him. She stared at him in confusion and worry and he never wanted to see it cloud her eyes again. He kissed her, his tongue sliding against hers, claiming her. He felt so fierce and protective of her. He rolled them to his good side, hitched her leg over his hip, and slid inside her. With a moan, she gripped his shoulder, leaned back, and rolled her hips against his.

 

It didn’t matter where they were or what they were doing, being inside her was home. She was home. She was feisty, strong, intelligent, beautiful, and his love. She made everything else disappear.

 

He cupped the back of her head and brought her lips to his, kissing her as he thrust forward. Her fingers dug into his arse as she bit his lip. His wolf. Her bull. He traced along her throat and stopped at her pulse, feeling it thump against his tongue. The rapid beat calling to him. He licked, bit, and sucked at it, her movements growing erratic against him. He slid down her throat, the stubble of his beard leaving red tracks in their wake, and took a rosy bud into his mouth, teasing with teeth and tongue.

 

He felt her fingers brush against his cock and he reached down and pushed her hand away, stroking her the way he knew she liked. Soon, she was writhing faster, clutching at him harder, then she stilled. Her eyes fluttered closed, her breathing stopped for just a moment until she released the breath, her body shaking. Her walls clenched around him, pulling him tight. He buried his face in her neck as he kept thrusting, feeling it building at the base of his spine. The dig of her blunt nails into his lower back, the way she bit his lower lip and moaned his name, pushed him closer and closer. She pulled back and looked him in the eyes, a smile on her face, and he came, grunting her name. His beautiful, fiery warrior was his and would be his forever.

 

They lay entwined in one another until she kissed his lips and pulled away from him, though, she didn’t move off the bed. Instead, she lifted his arm and examined the bandages. He couldn’t see the wounds, but the look on her face was almost serene if she was even capable of looking that way. “No blood.” She sat back on the bed and brought her knees to her chest as she stared at him. He knew he had a stupid grin on his face and he couldn’t seem to make it go away. “You’re making me uncomfortable the way you’re smiling at me.”

 

“Would a scowl work better?”

 

She shook her head and smiled. “No. But, as uncomfortable as it makes me, I am very glad to see you smile.”

 

“It’s for you. You make me happy. I hope I make you happy.”

 

Her expression changed to one of concern. “Of course you do. How could you even doubt that?”

 

He shook his head and took her hand. “I don’t. Not really.” He paused, trying to think of the right thing to say, to assure her of his faith in them. “I love you. I want to be with you until my last day and I will do anything and everything to make sure you know that.”

 

She smiled and moved into his arms. “I believe you. I believe in you.”

 

*~*

 

The next morning found them in the hall, breaking their fast with their people. Lord Selwyn entered with his guard and both Gendry and Arya stood to greet him.

 

“My Lord, it is very good to see you,” Lord Selwyn said with a bow of his head.

 

“It is good to be seen, My Lord. Will you join us?”

 

“I would be honored. Though I must tell you, I have plans to leave this afternoon. I am going to ride to the harbor and take my ship to White Harbor then go on to Winterfell.”

 

Arya smiled beside him. “My brother and sister will be more than happy to welcome you. And I’m sure Brienne will be thrilled.”

 

Gendry offered him the seat beside Arya. “I want to meet her fellow, make sure he’s a good match for my daughter.”

 

He was struck mute, unsure how to actually convey what Tormund was. “I know he cares very much for her. I believe her squire said, once, that it was love at first sight for him.”

 

Arya nodded. “And believe me when I say that your daughter wouldn’t tolerate anything less than someone who treats her with the respect she deserves.”

 

Lord Selwyn gave them a small smile. “It fills my heart to hear you speak so highly of my daughter. I worried for a long time that she wouldn’t be able to find her way in the world, given how most people look down on women fighters.” He looked at the table and Gendry wondered what memory made him smile in such a way. He glanced at Arya and saw a smile on her face but it didn’t reach her eyes. He reached over and took her hand, knowing he would have time to ask her later. She squeezed his fingers as she sipped at her wine.

 

“So, tell me about Winterfell and your brother and sister, if you don’t mind.”

 

Arya turned her attention to him fully. “It would be my pleasure.”

 

*~*

 

They stood in the courtyard to see Lord Selwyn off, Arya asking him to deliver a letter to her sister, which he seemed more than happy to do. She missed her family, and it had been clear to see when she spoke of them earlier. He watched her as she looked around nervously, rubbing a hand at the back of her neck.

 

“Are you alright?” he whispered.

 

“I have the feeling someone is watching me. Us. Whether or not there are more Faceless Men in the keep, Melisandre is still here.”

 

He nodded, knowing she still had the desire to kill the woman, not that he would keep her from it. Arya doled out her own justice as she should.

 

The squawk of a raven sounded overhead and as Gendry watched it fly, it dived at them, flying in Arya’s face. Everyone in the yard was stunned, but he noticed the note tied to its leg and removed it. Its white eyes turned to the normally black hue and the raven dropped to the ground. Gendry squatted down to see about the raven only to realize it was dead.

 

“Bran,” Arya whispered.
