One of the guards came and removed the bird as Gendry led her to their place on the cliffs, Harry and Peeta following them. They stood at the stone wall to keep anyone else from joining them. He held up the letter, it was addressed to her. She tore at the seal and read it softly to herself then turned and looked at him, her eyes clouded with rage.

 

“What does it say?”

 

“It’s about the Faceless Men,” she responded.

 

“Read it,” he whispered.

 

“ Arya,

 

I’ve had a vision and I know of Gendry’s injury and the Faceless Men in your keep. They were the only two, but you know as well as I that they will not stop until their job is fulfilled and they have captured their name or the person to pay them has died. Your traitor is Maester Juren. When I looked into his past, it would appear that he is the bastard brother of Robert, Stannis, and Renly. His father’s progeny from before his marriage to their mother.  He wanted the seat of Storm’s End for himself but heard of one of Robert’s bastards still roaming around. Once he received word of Gendry being named Lord and being sent to Storm’s End, he sought out the services of the Faceless Men. He only saved Gendry’s life with the antidote because you threatened his life should Gendry die. He’s still intending to kill Gendry, and you. Be careful sister. More news from King’s Landing will reach you soon from Jon. Some of it good, some of it bad.

 

Stay safe.

 

Bran Stark”

 

Gendry frowned and shook his head. “A hidden Baratheon?”

 

“Gendry, he has access to us. We have to stop him.”

 

“We will. But...let me confront him.”

 

She grey eyes grew angry. “I was the one who nearly watched you die!”

 

“I know,” he said as he cupped her face. “I’m not saying you don’t have a right. But he’s my family by blood. He could have done this several ways and yet he chose our deaths. I want to know why.”

 

She shook her head. “Because he was greedy for power.”

 

“You’re probably right. But I still want to hear it from him.”

 

“And if you don’t.”

 

He shrugged. “He dies for being a traitor either way. Prepare a raven to send to the Citadel telling them we need a new maester and one to the Faceless Men telling them their client has been killed and it’s his name, not mine, they were given. Find out how much they were going to be paid and let’s make sure we pay them more so they don’t come after us.”

 

Arya nodded. “I will. Once he’s dead.”

 

“Come with me,” he said as he held his arm out for her to take. She did and they walked back into the keep.

 

*~*

 

Maester Juren entered his library, stopping abruptly at seeing Gendry seated in one of the chairs at the table, looking over the book of Baratheon lineage.

 

“My father never mentioned the fact he had Targaryen blood when he was trying to wipe out Targaryens,” he said to the man as he looked up. “The very thing that actually gave him a claim to the throne was the one thing he hated most in this world. Funny how that happens, isn’t it?”

 

The maester nodded. “I suppose, My Lord. Can I help you find something?”

 

Gendry shook his head and smiled. “I found it already. A lineage of House Baratheon.” He watched the man’s reaction. His face remained impassive if a little irritated. “You see, I had this dream while I was under. My father, Stannis, and Renly were all there. Told me I was the future of our house and would bring honor to its name. To be honest, it’s hard to believe that sometimes. I still feel like a bastard from Flea Bottom, no better than the muck on someone’s shoes.”

 

“People often underestimate bastards,” the maester said. “They can climb high if they have the ambition.”

 

“I always lacked ambition for power, I suppose,” he responded with a shrug. “I only wanted to live and own a forge. Never thought I would be the lord of a keep, betrothed to a lady of a great house, in command of people and their lives,” he said as he looked back at the book. “I do have a question.”

 

“Yes, My Lord?”

 

“There is a page in front of my father’s that’s blank.” He looked up. “That doesn’t happen anywhere else in the book. Do you know why?”

 

He could see the pulse jump in the man’s neck and his jaw twitch before he answered. “Some people believe, My Lord, that your father had a bastard older brother. Your grandfather's issue before he married your grandmother.”

 

Gendry tilted his head. “I haven’t heard that. Imagine that? I’d have family. A blood relative. An uncle.” He looked back at the book. “How much we would have in common. Both bastards, left in obscurity, forgotten by those who created us.”

 

“I suppose that’s true.”

 

He smiled at the maester, though he didn’t feel it. “I wonder if he’s still living? We could throw a feast, welcome him in as part of the Baratheon legacy. I could even write to the king and queen and ask that they legitimize him...”

 

“My Lord, that would negate you as Lord of Storm’s End,” he sputtered in surprise. Gendry was sure that the thought that one would be so generous and relinquish power probably never occurred to him.

 

He shrugged. “I never intended to be Lord,” he replied and frowned, knowing it was true. How his life had changed since Davos found him on the Street of Steel. “The king and queen asked this of me and I did it because I thought I could make people’s lives better. At least, better than mine had been.”

 

The maester didn’t say anything as Gendry flipped to the page after Renly and frowned. “You haven’t added me, yet.” The comment was meant to be casual, but when Gendry looked up, he narrowed his eyes. “Is it because you had no intention of letting me get very far in being Lord of Storm’s End?”

 

The maester looked up at him sharply. “I beg your pardon?”

 

He stood and took a step forward. “I know who you are. I know you’re my father’s older brother. A bastard like me...yet you’ve been hiding in plain sight. You had the opportunity to claim this keep as yours for years, tell people who you were, but you didn’t. Why did you wait?”

 

“I’m afraid I don’t understand,” the man stuttered.

 

The door closed behind him and he turned abruptly to see Arya.

 

“I don’t even need to ask her if you’re lying. You understand. You are my lost uncle,” he said softly. “So, tell me, why were you hiding? The castle had no Lord.”

 

He took a step back from Gendry. “Who would believe me?”

 

“Given the Baratheon reputation, probably more than you’d think. You could have told me when we arrived. Did you think I would turn you away? Have you killed?”

 

“Yes. I was a threat to your claim,” he answered honestly.

 

“You decided to do it without getting your hands dirty, though. How did you know of the Faceless Men?”

 

“I lived in Braavos. Everyone knew of the Faceless Men,” he looked at Arya and Gendry, “I didn’t know they would kill Mary and Natasha. That was unforeseen.”

 

“You traded their lives for your own ambition,” Arya seethed. “And considering what they went through before...I hope it eats at you.”

 

“And what are you going to do to me?”

 

“You tried to have us both killed. You conspired with our enemies to see me and my lady dead. That’s treason.”

 

The door opened and Ser Farring, Peeta, and Harry entered. Ser Farring turned disgusted eyes on the maester.

 

“That seat is rightfully mine,” Juren hissed. “I demand a trial by combat, and I should be allowed to choose a champion.”

 

“And you would have them fight me?” Gendry questioned, though he wondered if he would be able to beat whoever it was that the maester chose. He wasn't fully healed.

 

He nodded. “Yes. To the death.”

 

“I know how it works. And who is your champion.”

 

“Gregor Clegane. I simply have to send a raven...”

 

“The Mountain isn’t available for combat. Raven from my brother arrived while you weren’t here. They took King’s Landing and the Mountain died at the hand of his brother, Sandor Clegane,” Arya said with a tilt of her head, holding up the scroll.

 

The maester looked panicked. “Ser Farring. We have known one another for years. Both kept here under Lord Stannis and Lord Renly. Surely you would fight for an old friend.”

 

“I don’t fight for murderers,” he spat. “Those two girls your assassins killed were innocent. Their blood is on you. I won’t do anything to help you.”

 

Arya clasped her hands behind her back. “It appears you have no allies. Do you still wish for trial by combat?”

 

He shook his head. “I do wish for a trial.”

 

“In front of the king and queen?” Gendry snorted. “I’m sure they would be quite receptive to a man who tried to murder the king’s sister and her betrothed.”

 

The maester suddenly pushed Gendry back and ran up the stairs, the soldiers, and Arya giving chase. Gendry followed until they came to one of the many open areas of the keep. The wind was fierce and harsh, rain pelting them. The man was cornered and Gendry stepped forward between his guards. “Surrender and your death will be as quick and painless as possible.”

 

Juren looked out over the ledge, then narrowed his eyes at Gendry. “I would have been a great Lord,” he said and jumped from the ledge. Everyone rushed to the edge. Gendry got there just as he hit the ground. He winced and stepped away.

 

Ser Farring turned to Gendry and shook his head. “I had no idea.”

 

“You couldn’t have known who he was. He was the maester the Citadel sent,” he replied. He turned to Harry and Peeta. “Fetch his body and make sure it is sent back to the Citadel.”

 

“Yes, My Lord,” Peeta answered and they left to do his bidding.

 

“Ser Farring?”

 

“Yes, My Lord?”

 

“I’m sorry about your friend,” he said softly. “That couldn’t have been easy for you.”

 

He was silent for a moment and then sighed. “It was not, My Lord. He has been my friend for a long time. However, I hired Natasha and Mary when they were young girls. They came here because their families had died during the war and they needed work. Natasha was twelve,” he said as he shook his head. “They were innocent. Abused by those men and then killed by assassins trying to get to you because of him. I mourn their loss.”

 

“I’m truly sorry. I heard you took care of their bodies,” Gendry said as he started down the stairs, Ser Farring following.

 

“I did. Juren helped. He was so upset over losing them, and I suppose now I know why.”

 

“Guilt,” Arya answered ahead of them.

 

Ser Farring frowned. “May I clean out his rooms, My Lord?”

 

“You may. Thank you, Ser Farring. I know I haven’t been here long, but I am happy to have you here to help us protect the people in this keep.”

 

He straightened, a proud look upon his face. “It is my honor, My Lord. You and your lady have proven to be people of character and good faith. I will serve you both, with honor, for the rest of my days.”

 

Gendry nodded. “Thank you.”

 

*~*

 

“I can’t believe Tyrion is dead,” he said with a sad tone as he reread the letter from Bran later that night. “I was certain he would be the Lannister that survived.”

 

“No, that would be Jaime. The sparkle in my sister’s eye,” she said as she came out of the bathroom and sat beside him on the bed. “I suppose, if he has any honor, which is doubtful, he’ll ask for her hand and they’ll get married at the sept at Casterly Rock.”

 

“She loves the North.”

 

“Sometimes there are things more important than a location.”

 

“Have I told you today how glad I am to have you?”

 

She shook her head and put the letter beside the bed and snuggled into him. “No, but I believe you showed me yesterday morning.”

 

He grinned. “You’re just damn sexy when you wear tunics like that. Hard to resist.”

 

“You keep up that sweet talk and I’m going to start  wondering if maybe you’re a faceless man.”

 

Gendry looked at her. “When do you want to get married?”

 

“That killed that suspicion.” She sighed. “I don’t know. I’d like to send notice to my family. Jon, Sansa, Bran...”

 

“Maybe some of them can come.”

 

“Maybe. I know you’d like to do it sooner than that.”

 

He smiled. “But that’s just me wanting nothing more than you.”

 

She leaned over and pressed a kiss to his lips.

 

“Can I ask you a question without you getting mad?” he asked.

 

“Depends on the question.”

 

“You didn’t have moon tea with your meal.”

 

She suddenly stilled and looked at him. Fear ran along her face. “I..I didn’t take it before your attack because it was poisoned. We currently don’t have any. They threw out the whole batch cause they thought the whole crate might be poisoned. Gendry...”

He wrapped his arms around her. “Whatever, or whoever comes, we will face it together.”

Meera II

Chapter Summary

Meera and Bran grow closer and news from the south gets everyone in a tizzy.

Chapter Notes

Phew, been a while, hasn't it? I apologize. I'm still going through recovery from my third back surgery. A huge thanks to the community for even making that happen. You have no idea how much it meant to get the love and support from this wonderful group of people. I was truly humbled and stunned. So, from the bottom of my heart, thank you!

I know some of you are wondering about my fics and the truth is that I'm trying to write as much as I can. The problem is I just simply don't feel like it. This just hit me the other day and I ran with it. I feel like I'm letting the community down. My goal was to finish this fic before the premiere, but I don't think that's going to happen. However, I will do my best to get as much of it posted for you guys before April. My other fics, for the moment, will take a back seat to getting this up. Apologies.

And I would like to send a huge shout out to the lovely tarts. Being my friend lately has been less than fun. I feel like all I do is complain to the point where I've been sort of staying away from people because I don't want to bring anyone down. But these ladies are amazing and can make me laugh more often than not. And then the Kit spams are always nice. THANK YOU to all of you for being so amazing. And a huge thanks to my partner in crime, justwandering-neverlost for the gorgeous mood board and the beta. Don't know how I would make it without you!

MEERA


She stood in the stirrups of the horse as it ran through the woods, her arrow aimed at the upcoming target, and released at the right time. She pulled a new arrow from the quiver at her back as she watched another hit the target to her left and smiled back at Bran. There was one more. Steering her horse down the path, she released the reigns, stood and fired again. As she reached the clearing of the woods and Bran caught up with her, she smiled to see his red cheeks and his smile. “I hit two.”


“Better than none. And you’re getting better,” she encouraged.


Podrick came out of the woods only a few seconds later followed by Riff. Podrick moved in behind them as Riff led the way back to Winterfell, allowing Meera and Bran to ride together and have some privacy. “How is Sansa doing?” she finally asked.


Bran shrugged. “She hasn’t talked to me about any of it. Not Tyrion, Jaime, or Arya.”


She frowned. “Do you think it’s because she knows you have an unfavorable opinion on it all?”


“Probably. She’s been talking to Brienne.”


“Have you been watching her conversations?” Meera asked, curious if he would see that as an invasion of her privacy.


“No. She’s training a lot more. Used to be just in the morning. Now it’s at night as well.” Bran frowned. “She angry.”


“Jaime Lannister pushed you out of a tower when you were a boy. It’s unreasonable for her to believe you would ever allow him to live here.”


Bran sighed. “Thank you for understanding.”


“I do. I understand.” She tilted her head at him. “But I also understand what it’s like to be in love with someone you can’t have.”


He shook his head. “She deserves better.”


“That’s not for you to decide, is it? Yes, you’re her brother, but you don’t get to decide her fate or who she marries.”


“He’s done horrible things, Meera.”


“I believe you. It’s just that as much as I’ve talked to your sister, I can’t believe she would fall in love with someone who was still like that. Didn’t you say he rode north even when Cersei said it would be treason?”


“Yes.”


“And he’s been loyal to the king and queen since?”


Bran nodded. “Yes.”


“And he saved Sansa’s life?”


He huffed out a sigh. “Yes. All that’s true.”


“Perhaps he’s changed. You have. I have.” She shrugged. “It’s not completely outside of reason that he has.”


“So I’m supposed to let the man who nearly murdered me come north and claim my sister?”


She shook her head. “No. I think he has to be held accountable for what he did to you. He should be banished from the North and if he ever returns, then he’s to be brought to you for justice.”


“I don’t understand the solution.”


Meera stopped her horse and Bran did his too, which caused Pod to stop, as well as Riff. “She doesn’t think she can leave you. She believes her duty is here as Wardeness of the North because you need her. Perhaps you should tell her, or better yet, show her that you can do this without her. Then, if he asks for her hand, she’s free to go to Casterly Rock to be with him.”


He looked at Winterfell and frowned. “I don’t want her to leave.”


She reached over and took his hand. “I know. But she’d leave eventually, anyway. She’s going to marry someone.”


He squeezed her hand. “Thank you.”


“For what?”


“Making me see it from a different point of view.”


She gave him a small smile and released his hand. “You’re getting better shooting from the saddle.”


“Right, another five years and I might be half as good as you,” he deadpanned. They entered the walls of Winterfell and as she dismounted from her horse, she was met by the maester.


“A raven for you, my Lady.”


She took the parchment and opened it.


Meera,


Congratulations are in order for your engagement to Lord Bran. He will be a good husband to you. I will have already left home and be on the road by the time you receive this letter. I look forward to standing at your side as you take your husband. I am so proud of the woman you are.


Father


Bran was seated in his chair once more and looked up at her expectantly. “From your father?”


She gave him a smile. “He’s already on his way to Winterfell.” She looked at her betrothed and tilted her head. “This is all happening so quickly.”


He nodded. “It is. But our wedding isn’t for a while. You’ll still be...you can still back out, if you want.”


She narrowed her eyes at him. “Why would you say that?”


“I only say it because I want what’s best for you.”


She looked at Pod. “Take him to the solar. It appears we still have some items to discuss.”


*~*


“Do you not want to marry me?” Meera asked, feeling her blood quicken and her temper rise.


“More than anything.”


“Then explain yourself,” she demanded. They had both remained silent as they had gone to the solar, but she was done with holding her tongue.


“It’s my own self-doubt. Why would you ever want to marry a cripple?”


Meera folded her arms over her chest. “You do realize that I’ve never known you when you had the use of your legs?” He nodded. “And still you think this?”


“I know it doesn’t make a lot of sense given that I asked you here to give me another chance, with the intention that I want to marry you.”


“You’re right. It doesn’t. You know me well enough to know that I won’t be talked into doing something I don’t want to do. You and I have traveled a long road together, Bran, and I intend for that road to continue on for the rest of our lives. I won’t have you second guessing it, now.” He looked thoroughly chastised and she sat in front of him. “Even if you doubt it, I want you to know that I’m where I want to be and with the man I want to marry. I didn’t make the decision lightly. You know that. So, if you doubt your judgment, ever, trust mine?”


He gave her a slow smile. “I think I can do that.”


“Good. No more of this changing my mind talk.”


“No more.” She leaned over and pressed a kiss to his lips. He was blushing when she pulled away.


A knock at the door ceased any teasing she might have done. Bran bid them to enter and Sansa walked in with Brienne. “I saw you two ride in. You’re looking more confident on a horse as the days go by, Bran.”


He smiled at his sister. “Thank you, Sansa.”


“A raven from the citadel proclaiming that Cersei Lannister has been deposed and Daenerys and Jon have taken the throne with their coronation in a month.”


Meera smiled. “Good news all around this day.”


Sansa took a deep breath and gave them both a smile. “I feel like our family was due good news.”


Bran smiled back and reached for Meera’s hand. “Indeed, we were.”


*~*


They were walking into the Godswood, Meera pushing his chair as Podrick followed behind but at a good distance to give them privacy. “What is your father like?” Bran asked to break the silence.


“He’s a good man. It was quite irritating to grow up with him with plans to do and get away with mischief. He always seemed to know what we were going to do or had already done. Once Jojen started getting his own visions it was a little easier to circumvent.” She thought about her brother and how they had left his body out amongst the cold of the North. She wished she had something of his to give back to their father.


“Do you think he will like me?”


She smiled. “Not worth even worrying over. He gave me your letter knowing what it said inside. If he didn’t think you were worth hearing out, he would have told me.” They stopped at the heart tree and she tucked the blanket around him better. “I believe you will get on very well with my father.”


He took her hand. “Your confidence does make me feel better. I think my father would have liked you,” he said softly


“Oh?”


He nodded. “You want to protect those you care about, fierce loyalty, a good daughter to her father. You’re also quite like my sister, Arya, and take fighting and weapons training seriously. He always seemed to encourage that with her.”


“And your mother?” she asked, deciding to take them further into the Godswood.


He sighed. “I don’t know, really. I think she would like that you come from a reputable house, you don’t look down on me for being a cripple, and I feel this is the most important issue, you make me very happy.”


She blushed. “I’m not a proper lady like Sansa.”


“If I wanted one of those I could find one. I want you. I want the person who was by my side when I became more than Bran Stark. The woman who understands what it’s like to suffer loss. Hodor, Summer, Leaf, Jojen, Osha. Rickon,” he said as he hung his head.


She stopped pushing him and came around to stand in front of him, taking his face into her hands. “What happened to Rickon is not your fault. You sent him away to protect him. There was no way you could have known what was to come.” He looked down but her hands tightened on him and his eyes focused on her again. “If Rickon had been with us when the Night King came...we lost so much that night. I hate that Rickon died but I’m so glad I wasn’t there to bear witness.”


“But I have,” he hissed. “I’ve seen him die over and over again. I watched Jon, Robb, Rickon, my mother, and father. Maester Luwin. Ser Roddrick. I’ve seen them all die hundreds of times and it kills a part of me each time.”


“Why are you watching that?”


“To...find something, some way they could have escaped and lived,” he answered softly.


“Jon did live. He’s the King of the Seven Kingdoms.”


He shook his head. “There are only three true heirs of Ned Stark and two of them are girls and will take other names. I sometimes worry we’ll have trouble carrying on the name.”


She brushed a hand over his hair even as she blushed. “I have faith in us, Bran. The fates will give us heirs aplenty.”


“You aren’t worried?”


She shrugged. “I worry about a lot of things, but not that.”


“Our marital bed...”


“Will be a happy one. Either way.”


The crows in the trees all let out a cry at the same time and Bran’s eyes went white. They soon turned back. “Draw your arrow,” he ordered. “Podrick.”


Bran’ sworn sword came to their side quickly as out of the trees came three hulking men. “Well, well, well, looks like da warden of the da North be out late and with very little guard. We’ll take your heads to queen Cersei ourselves.


“Cersei is dead!” Meera called, holding her arrow straight at the largest of the three.


The men stopped their advance and looked at each other. “Clever trick. But when we get your sister our lives are all but made. This might make her a little happier, though.”


Meera saw Bran’s eyes go white and the large brute on the left went stiff. Podrick stood in front of them and the man on the right advanced first, his strength the only advantage he had over Pod who was lighter on his feet, and soon his sword drove through the neck of the brute. The leader came for them but her arrow hit him in the shoulder. She had her bow reloaded before the third brute barreled him over.


Bran!


She took aim again, waiting for the tussle to finish and fired an arrow that caught the leader in the chest, keeping him on his knees. Podrick drove his sword through his heart, and kicked the body to the side. The third still knelt in the snow. Bran gasped as his eyes appeared normal once more and Podrick took a swing of his sword and lopped the man’s head from his shoulders.


Pod came back to them as they were joined by other Stark soldiers and soon after Brienne and Sansa who was sporting a bruised cheek. She rushed to Bran and threw her arms around his neck. “It’s alright,” he muttered to her. “Are you well?”


She nodded. “Managed to fight em off until Brienne and Wylla showed up.”


Tormund clapped Podrick on the back, a smile on his face. “Looks like all those mornings of getting your ass kicked worked.”


Podrick only blushed. Bran turned to Brienne. “Might I borrow your sword?”


She unsheathed it and handed it over. He laid it across his lap. Sansa stood to the left while Meera stood at his right. They both understood what was happening. “Podrick Payne,” Bran’s voice rang out over the woods. Everyone turned to the Warden of the North. Bran signaled for Pod to stand in front of him which he did, his head lowered.


“Kneel,” he said softly.


“My Lord,” he began to protest but Bran’s voice stopped him.


“You said you wanted to earn it. I believe you just did. Kneel.”


Podrick took a deep breath and took a knee in front of Bran. “I, Brandon of House Stark, Warden  of the North, Lord of Winterfell, do knight thee Ser Podrick Payne.” Bran nodded. “Rise, Ser Podrick Payne.”


Those gathered cheered and several men rushed forward to give their congratulations, Tormund being the loudest. “Tell the kitchens to prepare a feast for our new knight,” Bran proclaimed with a bright smile. Podrick, however, stayed with Bran, Sansa, Tormund, Brienne, Wylla, and herself.


Bran turned concerned eyes to his sister and Meera could see the bruises forming around her throat and even a trickle of blood. He held out his hand to her. “Are you sure you’re alright?”


She nodded. “They were hiding in my room after sword practice. Brienne and Wylla showed up at my door as Brienne was teaching her protocol. I suppose they heard me.”


“Barely,” Brienne reminded. “I heard her gasp and when she didn’t answer me, I kicked in the door. I apologize for the damage.”


“That damage as you called it, saved my sister’s life. Shall we knight you?” Bran asked and Meera looked up at Brienne with a smile. “You’ve earned the title over and over.”


Brienne blushed as Tormund stood nearby and watched her. “While that was what I wanted for so long, I’m more comfortable with what I am now, the sworn shield to Lady Sansa.”


Bran handed her sword back to her. “You simply give the word and I’ll be happy to knight you.”


Sansa smiled. “Anyone who has met you would be willing.”


“Brienne, Tormund, while I’m thinking about it, Arya and Gendry have sent a letter,” Bran went on. “Your father is on his way to Winterfell to see you and meet Tormund.”


“He wants to meet Tormund?” Brienne asked, eyes wide. Tormund looked unconcerned which Meera found rather endearing. He wouldn’t be swayed from his lady love by any force in this world.


*~*


The feast for Podrick was a boisterous affair. The men were determined to get the newly knighted man so drunk he would find it impossible to walk. Brienne, his mentor and trainer, had remained quiet ever since the news that her father was coming to Winterfell. Meera felt a kinship with the larger woman and approached her slowly.


“Lady Brienne.”


She turned and gave Meera a small smile. “Lady Meera.” After a moment, both smiled. “Please call me Brienne and I’ll call you Meera.”


“You have an accord. Are you alright?”


“Yes. Shaken up about another attack in this castle and on my lady’s life.” They both glanced at Sansa who was seated with Bran, both were laughing. “She fought them off.”


“You’ve trained her well.” She sighed. “Forgive me if I’m out of line, but I feel as if this is about more than just the attack.”


She nodded. “It is. My father has always encouraged me to be the woman I wanted to be. And...I love Tormund and his girls. But I don’t know how he will respond to Tormund being a Wildling.”


“How did you first respond to him?”


Brienne chuckled. “Horror and disgust. He had this way of looking at me that made me uncomfortable. He still looks at me that way.”


“Does it still make you uncomfortable?”


She shook her head and looked down into her wine goblet. “I know it for what it is now. He thinks he’s being charming. I haven’t the heart to tell him that it frightens other people.”


“I don’t think he’d care as long as it didn’t frighten you. It’s easy to see that Tormund loves you for who you are. I haven’t been here that long and I can see it. He’s a skilled fighter, a good man, and that he loves and respects you. That would matter more to my father than where he was born.”


“Your father travels here as well. Are you nervous?”


“No. But Bran is,” she said with a smile. “He doesn’t have Tormund’s confidence.”


Brienne snorted and rolled her eyes. “Who does?”


“It might help if we could get Tormund into Northron armor or garb.”


She shrugged. “That’s asking him to be someone he’s not. He’s never asked that of me. I would feel guilty to ask it of him.”


“Does he know you’re nervous?”


“Haven’t had the chance to speak about it, yet.”


“I’m sure if you tell him he’ll do everything he can to impress the man. Simply because he loves you.”


Brienne smiled. “You’re very wise for someone so young.”


She shook her head. “I’m in a similar position with a man who loves me.”


Sansa approached and gave them both a smile. “This feast will continue on for a few hours now. Tormund is going to force his special brew into Podrick.”


“That will kill him,” Brienne said, her face stern as she looked at the two women, bowed her head, and went in search of her lover.


“How are you? Did the Maester look at you?” Meera asked.


“Yes, and everything is fine. Just a little bruise,” Sansa assured her.


“You aren’t very shaken up?”


She shook her head and frowned. “Not the first time I’ve nearly died within these walls,” she said with a sigh.


“Hopefully the last,” Meera said softly. Sansa gave her a small smile before they both turned to survey the room. “How are you otherwise?”


“In what regard?”


“Arya and Gendry, the king and queen, Tyrion. Jaime.”


Sansa glanced at her hands briefly before looking up at the crowd once more. “I’m concerned for everyone. My sister isn’t one who will take the assault on Gendry lightly. The last time we were all attacked in the keep, Gendry was cut by a would-be assassin. I thought Arya was going to kill someone just to kill them.” She shook her head. “I’m worried for Daenerys and the babies she’s carrying. That much stress while pregnant can’t be good for her or them. But if I know Jon like I think I do, he’s being overly attentive and probably sleeping very little in order to take care of her and the needs of the people.”


Meera noticed how she grew quiet. “And Jaime?”


“I’ve lost two brothers. You’ve lost a brother. I think we know all too well the hole that leaves within you,” she said softly. “Knowing the circumstances of Tyrion’s death, I’m certain he probably blames himself for what happened.”


“What would you want, Sansa? If you could choose a scenario for yourself, what would you choose?”


She took a deep breath. “I’d want for the people I love to be happy.”


“What would you choose for you?”


She shook her head. “That is what I would choose for me. My youth was spent only thinking of myself and what I wanted. I wanted to marry Joffrey and live in King’s Landing. I wanted to make the queen happy. I wanted my father to stop interfering.” She shook her head. “I’d give almost anything to go back and change it and never leave. But, I’m here and I’m going to be the best at this as I can. I’ll help you and Bran become the best Wardens I can.”


“And your happiness?”


“Will come with time and patience,” she said softly. Sansa cleared her throat. “Your father should be here in less than a week. I’m sure you’re excited about his arrival.”


“I am. My betrothed is rather nervous.”


Sansa tilted her head as she examined her brother where he sat laughing with Podrick. “Should he be?”


Meera shook her head. “My father is like Bran. He sees things that others don’t.” She frowned. “He gave me Bran’s last letter and told me it was worth reading and supported my decision to come back to Winterfell. He’s always been fair.”


Sansa smiled. “I’m happy for you. Both of you,” she said as she looked out over the room and could see Brienne now drinking with Tormund. “If you’ll excuse me, I think I’ll save Brienne from herself.”


Meera chuckled and walked back to Bran and took his hand as she sat beside him. “It won’t be long and we’ll have a celebration like this for our wedding.”


Bran smiled at her. “I look forward to the day.”


She smiled back at him. “As do I.”

Jon XVI

Chapter Summary

Jon and Dany's council takes shape with a new Master of Ships and Mistress of Coin. The baby dragons are a terror at night. Ghost is very accommodating. Jon and Dany finally get to come together, again, after weeks of being apart.

Chapter Notes

Thanks to justwandering-neverlost for the gorgeous mood board.

Introducing an original character in here as I wanted something a bit different.

I'm going to try as hard as possible to get this fic finished before the premiere. I will be doing physical therapy and writing. That's what my life will consist of for the next few weeks.

Thank you all for your endless love and support. Thank you to those who have been with me since the beginning and those who have just started reading this fic. I appreciate all of you. When I started writing this fic, I had no idea it would be this long or have this many POVs. But you guys have stood by my side and been amazing. Getting reviews while doing all this recovery has been one of the shining lights for me. Just know how much I love and appreciate each one of you.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

JON

 

The dragons were worse than Ghost as a puppy. They didn’t like the confines of their small cages and squawked like birds through most of the night. Dany’s sleep was restless at the best of times, but four dragons that wanted her attention was driving him mad. It had been over a week since Tyrion’s funeral pyre and their hatching, but Jon had grown no more used to them than he had waking up in the Red Keep.

 

Sometime after the hour of the wolf, he finally climbed from bed and had a goblet of wine followed by another.

 

“My husband isn’t much of a drinker,” Dany commented from the bed.

 

“I can’t sleep.”

 

She turned on her side and faced the cages. “I don’t understand it. They’ve eaten. They’ve played. They’re just awake to be awake.”

 

He walked back to the bed and sat beside her. Her hand slid over his back and he cast a look at her over his shoulder. “Don’t start something we can’t finish.”

 

She smirked. “Funny you should say that. I talked to Dari and Sam and they both think that if we’re careful, then we can be together.”

 

He closed his eyes at the temptation being strung out before him. “I’m begging you, don’t tease me.”

 

She shook her head and threw the covers off her body as she pushed herself up to a seated position. “Come, have your wife, Jon Snow. You’ve more than earned it.”

 

He licked his dry lips and rubbed his fingers together. “You can’t let me have control. I don’t trust myself.”

 

She chuckled. “Get those trousers off and I’ll take care of you, my husband.”

 

He did as told and removed his clothes as Dany tossed her gown to the floor. The moonlight streaming through the window only added to the mystique of his otherworldly wife. Ripe with his child, staring at him with her striking eyes and soft smile. He slipped into bed with her, his mouth automatically seeking hers for comfort. She pushed him to his back and she straddled his waist, her hands slowly dancing over the bare skin of his chest and down to his length.

 

His wife was the most beautiful creature to walk the earth. He knew she was self-conscious about her hair, but it only served as a reminder to the world that Daenerys Targaryen was fearsome. Her eyes shown bright in the torches as she sat back and touched his cock. Easy strokes meant to drive him mad. “I don’t think you know, husband, just how much I desire you. All these nights spent sleeping in your arms, feeling you pressed against my back in the morning, has been a torment.”

 

His hands moved over her body, remapping her skin to get acquainted again. “End our torment, my queen.”

 

She rose up on her knees and slid him inside her. Bracing her hands on his shoulders, she made quick shallow thrusts. His head dropped back to the pillow, his hands smoothed over her skin. She gasped above him, her body weighing over his. He still wasn’t as deep inside her as he wanted to be, but he wouldn’t stop her for anything. She was glorious, a goddess of this world, and being inside her slick heat as she set the pace, as she lowered herself onto his hard cock over and over again was perfect. He felt guilty for wanting more, simply watching her with her head thrown back, her heavy breasts bouncing, her thighs clenched tight around his hips. How could he be so greedy as to want more?

 

But she gave him his silent wish as she leaned back, her hands on his raised thighs. Her silken walls clenched around him, holding his cock tight as she rocked. Her moans filled the room, and he was barely aware of the dragons all letting out shrieks of their own. “So close, Jon,” she moaned.

 

He slid his hand to her hips beneath the swell of her belly and found that spot within her folds to cause her to fall apart. A few strokes over it and she stilled, her body clenched, and he moaned at the feel of her around him. Suddenly she released and pushed down farther over his cock to which they groaned.

 

She braced her hands on his chest again while his were clenching the sheets. But the flutters of her inner walls around his cock caused him to loosen his grip and he grasped her hips, holding them as he thrust up into her. He felt it in the base of his spine, surprised he had even lasted so long in the first place. He watched where they were joined in fascination and then the sight of her fingers rubbing the little bud in her folds sent him over the edge.

 

He wasn’t sure what happened next as he closed his eyes, tiny explosions happening in the darkness. His mouth was suddenly dry and he knew for a fact he could not move. When he next opened his eyes, his wife was walking around their bedroom completely naked. She went to the water basin and cleaned herself up. He wanted to help her but he couldn’t feel his arms. He chuckled to himself, or so he thought.

 

“Why are you laughing?”

 

She brought a goblet of water to him but he shook his head and she placed it on the table by the bed.

 

“I can’t move.”

 

She smiled. “It’s been a long time.”

 

“It has. Only made more clear in my mind that you are the perfect woman. And there is no woman on this planet that I would rather spend my life with.”

 

She leaned down and kissed him. “You keep talking like that, Jon Snow, and I’ll tie you to this bed and never let you go. Save you for my own personal pleasure.”

 

“I would gladly serve you, my queen.” She smiled, then yawned. “But I believe my wife needs rest more than that, at the moment.” She snuggled in beside him, propping her belly against him and wrapping a leg over his thigh then reached for the covers. “I love you, Dany.”

 

She placed a kiss on his shoulder and yawned again. “Good. Makes it easier since I love you, too. Too much, I think.”

 

“Never too much,” he said as he finally found the strength in his arms to squeeze her.

 

*~*

 

There was a somber feeling in the room as their first council meeting was called. The seat of the Hand had been left empty, Davos claiming that while he still wanted to be the position, he hadn’t been made so officially, and until that time the chair would remain empty in difference to the previous Hand. Tyrion’s presence was sorely missed. Jon thought for sure there would be wine in abundance to celebrate this victory, but the reality was, though they won, there was heavy loss involved.

 

Dany sat to his left, a new garment having been made for her that supported her house colors while also embracing the warmer climate. Jon had followed her lead and also wore less cumbersome clothes, those that still had the silver of the Starks and the black of the Targaryens.

 

“Varys,” she said softly. “Have you found a new Master of Coin?”

 

The spider smiled. “I have indeed, Your Grace. She is known to be a shrewd mind and doesn’t take kindly to people spending money frivolously, and she’s extremely skeptical of the Iron Bank.”

 

“I look forward to meeting this woman.”

 

Varys nodded. “I shall call for an audience with her later today.”

 

Daenerys turned to him. “I think Lord Manderly of the North should be our Master of Ships. A reward for serving so bravely during the war and being our ally. We won’t need him at every council meeting, but we will need him.”

 

Jon gave her a smile. “I think that goes a long way to ingratiating us more to the North. I do have one matter of business we need to discuss. Follow me,” he said as he stood and held out his arm for his wife. Missandei, Varys, And Davos all followed. Before long they were standing in the throne room in front of the Iron Throne.

 

Daenerys nodded, “I agree it is an issue.”

 

“I want it gone,” Jon replied.

 

Daenerys walked slowly up the stairs and examined the throne but never sat in it. “I fought to get here. Everything I endured and suffered was to get here and sit on this throne and make the lives of other people better.” She looked out at them, frowning. “It’s part of my family’s legacy but...I’ve told everyone I want to break the wheel and Tyrion reminded me that Aegon Targaryen made the wheel.” She looked at her hands and the pain he saw on her face nearly made him walk up the stairs and pull her into his arms. He didn’t, though. He knew she might appreciate it later, but now, faced with her council, they needed to see and hear her as their leader. “Perhaps we should also consider a new strategy for ruling.”

 

Varys stepped forward and tilted his head. “What do you mean?”

 

“More voices from more walks of life. Ser Davos you’re from Flea Bottom. Missandei is from Naath. Varys is...from Essos. But there’s more than that to consider. How do the Westerlands feel about aiding the North should they start mining more heavily? And the Wildlings are living in the Gift, but how does that figure in for every person in the North that spent their lives in fear of them? We need more voices. More people to represent the people .”

 

“Are you abdicating?” Varys asked.

 

“No. We will still be King and Queen. But how can we help all of the people if they aren’t represented?”

 

Jon stared at her and took the steps to stand at her side. “You have ideas of how to accomplish this?”

 

“A few,” she said as she gave him a small smile. “Our Wardens should be implemented first to take care of smaller matters within their regions. But bigger issues, such as taxes or attacks could come through us. Our armies are still ours.”

 

“What of the Dothraki?” Davos asked. “Will they be staying?”

 

“I will give them and the Unsullied the right to choose to return to Essos or stay. We are not masters.”

 

Davos gave her a small smile. “No, Your Grace, you’re not. The Wardens?”

 

“Bran and Sansa in the North,” Jon answered. “Starks hold Winterfell and will continue to hold it for all nights to come.”

 

Dany nodded. “Sweet Robin is the Warden of the East. It’s a pact we made before we marched South.”

 

“That leaves the South and West.”

 

“The West will be Jaime Lannister,” Jon replied. Daenerys only looked at him but didn’t say anything. He gave his reasons anyway. “Even if he hadn’t held to his word and killed his sister, he has proven to be an honorable man. He rode North and fought beside us when he didn’t have to. He saved Sansa’s life, he saved the Queen’s life. He fought beside me at Harrenhall. Ser Jaime has earned it.”

 

“He’ll be released from the King's guard?” Varys asked and Jon would almost swear there was a smirk on the Spider's face.

 

“Yes. Let Ser Jaime live out his days in his ancestral home watching over his people,” Jon answered. “Through correspondence with my brother we have agreed that his punishment for nearly killing Bran as a child will be his banishment from the North for the rest of his life. Should he break that vow, Bran will exact Northron justice.”

 

“Have you discussed this with Ser Jaime?” Davos asked.

 

“Not yet. I was letting the rest of you know before we put our plan into action.”

 

Daenerys turned back to the group. “That leaves the South. With the Tyrell’s all gone...”

 

“Actually, Your Grace, I was informed only this morning that there is a member of House Tyrell that still lives, but he trains dogs and is lame due to a fight he had with Prince Oberyn Martell.”

 

“Who is this man?”

 

“Lord Willas. He abdicated being the heir once he was injured, and then it fell to Loras. Perhaps he’ll reconsider if he knows there are worse fates than losing the use of only one of your legs, and that a great man sits as Warden of the North who lost the use of his legs as a child,” Varys added.

 

“Find him, Varys. I’ll go meet him personally if that’s what it takes,” Jon replied.

 

“Yes, Your Grace.”

 

Davos nodded to the throne behind them. “And the Throne?”

 

Jon and Daenerys both turned to look at it. He locked eyes with her, willing to let her make the ultimate call but could see on her face she was willing to defer to him. He took her hand. “I never want our children to look upon this throne and think that this is where their power comes from. It comes from the people that make up this world as long as they are good and just.”

 

Dany gave him a nod and turned back to the group before them. “Find some stonemasons and metalworkers and see what it would take to have it removed.” She looked at Missandei. “Speak with the Unsullied leaders and let them know they are free to leave our service if they choose. We will send them wherever they want to go with wishes of good fortune.”

 

“And the Dothraki?” she asked.

 

“I shall handle my blood riders,” she announced.

 

“And should they decide to stay?”

 

“We’ll work something out with them. They already know that pillaging and raping are not allowed. They will hold to that. But I would never deny them the right to return to Vaes Dothrak if they desire. Thank you all for your wise counsel. I look forward to meeting with our new...Mistress of Coin.” Varys smiled and left the room, the others following. “Ser Davos, please wait.”

 

Jon watched her descend the stairs. “Jon said he spoke to you about being our Hand.”

 

“I know I’m not who you had in mind...”

 

She put a hand on his arm and Jon followed her. “You’re right. I didn’t choose you. My husband, my king , did. I trust his judgment. And I’ve come to know you as a fair and just man who speaks his mind even when it might not be smart to do so.” She reached into her pocket and held up the Hand symbol Tyrion had worn. “I had this made for you. Tyrion’s was gold but I thought you might appreciate dragonglass a bit more.”

 

Jon watched as Davos looked at her with a smile. “It will be an honor to serve you both. For the rest of my days.”

 

She slid it into place over his heart. “Ser Davos Seaworth, I name you Hand of the King and Queen.”

 

He knelt in front of them, but a staying hand from Jon kept him from the ground. “No, my friend. I’ll not have you bowing to me.”

 

Daenerys smiled. “Nor I.”

 

“Sets a bad precedent,” Davos argued. “You should let me.”

 

“We could let you tell people that we let you if it makes you feel better.”

 

Davos gave him a smile. “Depends on who asks.”

 

“Thank you for all you’ve done, Ser Davos,” she said as she placed a kiss to his cheek. “I trust that you’ll always tell us what we need to hear whether we want to or not.”

 

“I will. As long as you promise not to feed me to your dragons if you don’t like what I got to say.”

 

Daenerys smiled. “I agree as long as you are honest.”

 

He nodded. “I’ll have the throne seen about. What should we replace it with? We can’t have you two simply standing up there as you listen to your people.”

 

“No, I don’t suppose we can.”

 

“Something comfortable but still regal,” Daenerys added. “I’ve had enough of sitting on uncomfortable chairs.”

 

Jon smiled and looped her hand through his arm.

 

“Regal mixed with comfort. I’m sure that will be easy enough,” Davos joked before he turned to leave the room.

 

Once alone Daenerys looked back at the throne and sighed. “What do we do with it?”

 

“Melt it down. Make it into swords. Offer Valyrian steel to the heroes of the war,” he offered.

 

“Speaking of, you hadn't told me you sent a raven about Jaime to Bran.”

 

He heaved a sigh. “I know. I apologize. I wanted to have a strategy in place before it was discussed. I should have asked you...”

 

“You made the right decision. Jaime wants to be a good man. We simply have to let him.”

 

“With Bran’s recent engagement, it’s left Sansa’s position in Winterfell in question.”

 

He could tell she was biting back a smile. “And what do you think she should do?”

 

“Whatever makes her happy.”

 

She gave him a genuine smile and leaned in to kiss him. “Let’s go let the babies out of their cages for a while. They liked roaming around the balcony,” she responded, effectively ignoring his statement.

She looked at him. “Tired and achy. Carrying all this extra weight around is excruciating. My legs, hips, back, stomach, and other parts all ache.”

Daenerys led the way to the balcony and he opened the door for her. She sat on one of the settees as she released the dragons to the ground and Jon placed his two on the ground as well. They hopped around to each other, nipping and playing.

 

Ghost took that moment to come out to the balcony and settled near the open door. They all made their way to him, jumping and biting. He thought the direwolf was incredibly patient to endure it.

 

“Arylion,” Daenerys said as she picked up the purple dragon and it nuzzled her.

 

Jon smiled. “I like that name. I think Arya will like it, too.”

 

“She should be immortalized,” Daenerys said with a chuckle. “Fierce fighter that she is. Seems fitting that my sisters have a dragon named for them.”

 

It warmed his heart to hear Dany refer to Arya and Sansa as her sisters. Jon reached out a hand and pulled her to sit across his lap as the small dragon curled against her chest. “Did you ever fathom that our world would consist of babies and dragons?”

 

She pressed a kiss against his ear. “Dragons, yes. Babies, no.”

 

“I have to admit I am very happy that I proved that witch wrong.”

 

She chuckled. “You did a splendid job, my king.”

 

He heaved a deep breath. “My queen.”

 

“We have only one matter left to discuss: Theon.”

He leaned back in his chair. “South of Moat Calin.”

He frowned. “We’re not actually negotiating with Theon, though, are we? It’s Yara.”

 

“Queen Yara,” she corrected. “I think if Theon is happy with that arrangement then she will be as well.”

 

“She'll be ready to give birth soon,” he said softly.

 

She nodded. “We can speak to them this afternoon or tomorrow.”

 

“After you’ve had a rest,” he insisted.

 

“Don’t think you’re going to get to order me around now that I'm feeling better,” she said with a smirk.

 

He nuzzled his nose against her neck, inhaling the scent of foreign spices and smoke. His hand came up to rub over her belly as her lips pressed against his temple and her fingers traced through the curls at his nape. He watched the other dragons curl up beside Ghost, and the great wolf didn’t appear to even notice. Dragons, direwolves, and babies. Jon couldn’t help but think with his wife in his arms that he could handle anything the world threw at him.

 

*~*

 

Daenerys was meeting with Dari and Missandei about preparations regarding her pregnancy and eventual birth. Jon had gone to the small council room and had Davos meet with him and asked for a map of the North. Lord Manderly was also called in as he was currently mingled in the castle with the other Lords.

 

The large man eyed him curiously as he was escorted into the room and Jon gave him a smile. “My Lord, thank you for coming so quickly.”

 

“My King summoned me,” he said with a bow of his head.

 

“I’m using you as a proxy, but I wanted to run an idea by you, get your opinion before the queen and I make any firm decisions.”

 

“Of course, Your Grace. How can I help?”

 

“My Queen and I have both decided that we would ask you to be our Master of Ships. You’ve served us loyally and I know the reputation of your family when it comes to ship making. We could think of no one better for the job.”

 

Lord Manderly bowed his head. “This is a great honor, Your Grace. I will serve you to the best of my ability.”

 

“I have no doubt that you will,” Jon said with a nod. “You’re an honorable man and I know you will be an asset to the greater kingdom as a whole.” He then gestured at the map of the North. “As I’m sure you’ve heard, Queen Daenerys made a pact with Yara Greyjoy that she would recognize her as Queen of the Iron Islands for her help. We both intend to honor that pact. Queen Yara has made a request of the queen, though, and it’s one that we would like to find a way to honor but are uncertain how to do so.”

 

“I’ll help in whatever capacity I can, Your Grace.”

 

He looked at Davos then Lord Manderly. “Theon Greyjoy wants to live in the North. As you know, he rescued Sansa while she was being held by the Boltons. He also rescued his sister from the clutches of Euron Greyjoy and brought the Iron Fleet under our control during the final phase of the war.” He took a deep breath. “For those reasons, the queen and I have agreed to find a way to give him what he wants. A homestead in the North. But, too far North and he might run into some problems with Stark loyalists who might not accept that he betrayed Robb or took Winterfell. We’ve been looking at this map, trying to figure out where best to allow him to do what he wishes.”

 

Lord Manderly looked at the map. “Your Grace, given that the Greyjoys do have experience with sailing, it might be prudent to keep him close to White Harbor. His knowledge might somehow be useful. It would also allow my family to keep an eye on him.”

 

“My Lord, that is more than gracious of you to do. He's agreed to serve the Starks if banners are called, but you should also know that he will be raising the baby his sister is currently carrying. The child will have no claim to the Iron Islands, but will essentially be Theon’s child.”

 

“All the more reason to allow me to be close to keep an eye on him. I take it that as your Master of Ships I won’t be in the capital all the time?”

 

“No, in fact, we would like you to assign a proxy that could be trusted to give counsel as you would.”

 

“I can most assuredly do that, Your Grace. Send Theon Greyjoy to me and when I go back to White Harbor he can travel with me and my men to make sure he is assured safety.”

 

“That is very kind of you, my Lord.”

 

He looked at the map. “Your father was an honorable man, Your Grace. Ned Stark didn’t punish a child for the sins of the parents. I will not do that either. I will work out a compromise with Theon Greyjoy that I believe will work to everyone’s benefit.”

 

“Thank you.”

 

The door opened and Daenerys walked in. He smiled at her. She was followed in by Varys and Missandei. Lord Manderly bowed to her as she entered. “Your Grace.”

 

“My Lord.”

 

“I was discussing with Lord Manderly our decision to make him Master of Ships and also about the best place for Theon.”

 

She looked up, hopeful at that news. “And did you discover somewhere?”

 

Jon nodded to Lord Manderly and the older man began speaking. “Yes, Your Grace, I believe we’ve thought of a great compromise. Theon Greyjoy will settle near White Harbor where I will be able to keep an eye on him and also use his knowledge of sailing and such to our advantage at times. He will be loyal to House Stark and be their bannerman.”

 

Daenerys nodded and smiled. “That sounds like a fair compromise I can put forth to the Queen.” He gave her a smile. “And since you are part of our small council, you’re free to hear Varys has informed me that our new Mistress of Coin will be here shortly.”

 

She sat at the table and the others followed her lead. “How long will you stay before you take your men back North, Lord Manderly?”

 

“My wife is sailing to the capital to be here for your coronation. We will sail home after. We can take Theon Greyjoy with us if that is acceptable. I will work to make sure he has a fine homestead to keep him occupied.”

 

Daenerys nodded. “And we will provide a wet nurse for the child.”

 

“That is very kind, Your Grace.”

 

He gave a nod. “You said you’ll have a Mistress of Coin?”

 

“Yes. Varys has found us a suitable candidate for this job.”

 

At that moment, the door was opened by the Unsullied and a young woman entered the room. Her dark hair was done in simple braids and her dress was a beautiful brocade of green with pearl flowers sewn into it.

 

“Your Graces, may I present Lady Justine Proudmore. She has an impeccable eye and memory for numbers,” Varys introduced her.

 

Jon took a deep breath and tilted his head. “Welcome, my Lady. Please have a seat.” He nodded to one of the stewards standing in the corner and they handed her the large ledger to which she nodded at the young man. “We know little about you except that you come highly recommended by Lord Varys. Please tell us about yourself.”

 

She held her head high and looked at Varys. “I grew up wanting to be a Maester to learn as much as I could. When my father discovered I could simply look at numbers and do the arithmetic in my head, he put me to work taking care of his books. I’ve been doing that since I was ten.”

 

“Ten?” Daenerys asked. “A truly gifted child. I feel we’re at an advantage to have you in our council.”

 

“Full disclosure, since Lord Varys didn’t tell you everything, the establishments that I ran the ledgers for were brothels. We were often in competition with Littlefinger, but he spent money like it was water. My father was more frugal, but our finances have been better than his.”

 

Jon looked at Varys, finding the choice of Mistress of Coin to be a rather interesting find. “You worked in the brothel?”

 

“Only ever doing the ledgers,” she assured.

 

Daenerys gave her a small smile. “We would not have judged you harshly if you had been a whore. Our council is made up of a vast array of people. Lord Manderly is from the North, our Master of Ships. Missandei was a slave girl from Essos. Ser Davos, our Hand, was a smuggler. Lord Varys...well, the Spider keeps his own secrets. As for the King and I, he was thought to the be bastard of Lord Eddard Stark. He served as Lord Commander of the Night’s Watch. I’m an exiled princess sold to a Dothraki warlord and now Queen.” She gave the woman a nod. “There is no judgment of you from anyone on this council, my Lady.”

 

“I’m not a Lady.”

 

“You will be addressed as one in our presence,” Jon assured her. “And while you’re here, we do want you to look at our finances. We know the Iron Bank does not care which monarch is in charge, the debt of the crown is debt. Daenerys and I simply want to know what amount the debt is and also who else we might owe money to.”

 

Lady Proudmore gave a nod. “I will have an answer for you in a few days. Thank you for allowing me this opportunity.”

 

“Of course,” Daenerys answered. “We would like you to live in the castle. For your own safety. We will be working alongside you, often, to manage the debt.”

 

She opened the book and turned to the last page that was written on and her brows knit together. “Your debt to the Iron Bank, just for the Golden Company, is incredibly high.”

 

Jon nodded. “Have a look deeper and make sure. We need to know what we’re dealing with should one of them decide it’s time to collect.”

 

“Yes, Your Grace. Do you have the figures already spent for your coronation?”

 

Davos nodded. “I’ve been keeping a tally. I’ll be sure you have it before you leave the Red Keep.”

 

Jon stood then and looked at the group before him. “Daenerys and I want to change the world and make it better. We’ll start small, local. We’ll work to make Flea Bottom a better place. Restore some of the housing.”

 

“With what money?” Lady Proudmore questioned.

 

Daenerys looked at Jon with a smirk. “We will ask for volunteers,” she answered. “I’m sure the people there would like to see it become better. Materials...well, we have some already. We’ll find ways to gain more.”

 

“We’re gonna start a new way of living. We’ll give more people a voice,” Jon went on. “The queen and I are working with Davos and will be working with the Wardens to make sure that people from every walk of life have a voice represented in front of us. We want to hear the people and make their lives better. If any of you have suggestions we will take them.”

 

*~*

 

He entered their chamber to find Daenerys seated at the table already putting food on her plate. He had gone to watch Lady Proudmore off to her home with the expectation that the Unsullied would escort her and return the next day to help her move her things to the castle. Daenerys was famished and he’d sent her to their chambers to eat.

 

He removed his cloak and boots, setting them by the fire. The second he did, Arylion came out of nowhere and nipped at his ankle. He hadn’t realized the cages were open and looked to an amused Daenerys. She was sitting back in her chair as she sipped at her drink. “Why are they out?”

 

“I’m hoping if they get to run around a bit more before we tuck them away for the night then we’ll be able to get some sleep.”

 

“That would be nice. I think we could both use it,” he said as he sat in the chair beside her. “How are you?”

 

“I’m tired, but I’m doing fine. Babies are fine. Moving around, kicking me the ribs and the bladder...”

 

He smiled and rubbed her belly and leaned over to place a kiss on it. “Stop kicking your mama,” he whispered.

 

She brushed a hand over his face, a serene smile on her own. “I love you.”

 

“And I love you.”

 

“Eat, Jon Snow. I intend for you to take me tonight as well.”

 

“We can eat later,” he teased.

 

She brought her finger up to her lip and tapped it in thought. “I would, but your daughters are making me feel as if I haven’t eaten in six days.”

 

“Very well. I’ll let you eat, we’ll get the dragons settled, and then I get to ravish you?”

 

She nodded. “Seems like a great plan, doesn’t it?”

 

“It is. Your brilliant mind is only one of the reasons I love you so much.”

 

Jon put food on his plate and leaned back in his chair before removing the tie holding his hair back and running his fingers through his curls a few times. “What did you think of Lady Proudmore?”

 

“I think she’s going to watch every dragon we spend. And perhaps she’ll figure out what to do about the Iron Bank, if they become an issue.”

 

“And if they do, and demand payment...”

 

“ If they’re foolish enough to do that, I think I might have to let them meet Drogon and Rhaegal. If for no other reason than to give us a bit more time to get what we need to pay them back. I think that should be the first priority.”

 

“Is there another sellsword company they could use to fight us?”

 

“There are a few. It comforts me, though, that we have Lord Manderly as our Master of Ships and Yara as an ally. Perhaps that will deter anyone from trying to attack.”

 

“And should someone attack the Iron Islands, we’ll prepare to support them as well.”

 

“Exactly. I like the idea of having Lord Manderly keep an eye on Theon too. It’s not that I don’t trust him, but I know you and your family don’t. Perhaps that can help Bran with allowing him to stay in the North.”

 

Jon nodded. “I’m sure it will.”

 

“Any word from Arya or Gendry?”

 

He shook his head. “Not from them, but through Bran. He said they’d rooted out the traitor and he paid for it with his life.”

 

She tilted her head. “And what if more faceless men show up?”

 

“I believe they’re both on the lookout for that, now.”

 

*~*

 

He returned from the privy and found her seated in front of the vanity, her fingers moving over the bit of fuzz that covered her head. He stepped up behind her and put both hands on her shoulders. “What has you looking like that, my love?”

 

Her eyes found him in the mirror, then she turned on the bench and took his hand. “Do you still find me desirable?”

 

His eyes widened as he looked down at her. “Alright, you’re not resting enough.”

 

“Jon...”

 

“No, that was a nonsensical question which means you’re tired.”  She stood from the seat and walked to the bed where she put her back to him. He didn’t know what was happening inside her head and she seemed very reluctant to tell him. But he couldn’t fathom why she would ask such a thing. “What’s the matter? Please tell me so I can help you,” he whispered.

 

She brought her fingers to her head once more and frowned over her shoulder at him. “You’re certain you don’t desire me any less?”

 

He stepped to her and turned her in his arms. “Is this about your hair?” He hoped it was something as simple as that.

“Hush,” he demanded. “You are the single most beautiful creature I have ever seen. With your hair or without it, that doesn’t change.” He hated seeing her so insecure. “Jon...Gods yes!”

 

Her silkened walls clenched around his finger and he pulled back to add in another. He licked his lips as she threw her head back, her own fingers tightening in his hair. She was taking deep breaths and when her eyes opened, more tears slipped out. She cupped his face, her thumbs tracing over his jaw. She shook her head and placed a kiss on his lips. “No,” she whispered. “You’ve never hurt me.”

 

He leaned his forehead against hers. “I hope that I never do.”

 

She smiled swiped at her tears. “I feel like I ruined the moment.”

 

He shook his head. “You didn’t ruin anything.”

 

She moved back on the bed and pulled him down with her. He followed, dropping his leathers onto the floor and joining her in the bed. His hands slid over her skin, stopping at the thumps against his hand at her belly.

 

“You sure you’re alright?”

 

Her smile was like a breath of spring. “Yes, Jon Snow. I’m fine. I was simply overwhelmed with how much I love you and how lucky I am to have you.” She heaved out a deep breath leaned into him, placing kisses along his throat.
