When he broke it, he was thrusting into her hands. “I want you inside me,” she whispered against his lips.

 

“I live to serve my queen,” he whispered back.

 

She chuckled and rolled away from him, putting her back to his front. He slid his arm beneath her head as he moved closer to her. He grabbed a pillow and tucked it beneath her belly, which earned him a peck on the cheek. He reached for her then and tucked her hips against his, sliding his cock against her folds a moment before burying himself inside her. Dropping his head to her shoulder he let out a groan. She stretched her leg back over his, thrusting into him slow and shallow like she had the night before. He allowed her to set the pace, not wanting to hurt her. Letting her get accustomed to it first was the best plan.

 

She shivered in his arms and turned her head to capture his lips. His arm wrapped around her shoulders as his other held her hip. He licked at her lips and she thrust back against him a bit harder. “More,” she demanded. She shook against him, her hands reaching back and gripping his hip as he thrust faster and a bit harder.

 

He was still wary of hurting her. Her head dropped to the pillow with a sweet moan. Loosening the grip he had on her hip he slid between her legs and swirled his fingers around her little nub again. Her gasp filled the room and body went rigid for only a moment, then shook in his hold. He was gone only moments after her, still holding her within the circle of his arms, his head pressed against hers.

 

“Dany,” he mumbled when he was finally able to regain his senses.

 

“Mmm?” her voice was soft and he wondered if he woke her.

 

“Never doubt how much I want you,” he whispered.

 

She was quiet and he didn’t know if she was already asleep. But she squeezed his hand and nodded. “I’ll try.”

Chapter End Notes

Lady Justine Proudmore is a play on Lady Jaina Proudmore from World of Warcraft. I made her look different than Jaina, but that's where the name came from. And I'm not a fan of the alliance either. I don't know why I chose that name. Just seemed like Proudmore fit in this world better than Windrunner. FOR THE HORDE!

Next chapters are as follows: Dany, Jaime, Arya, Sansa (I think I've worked out that there will be 106 chapters total. I hope you guys continue to enjoy this fic and I love you all for being so amazing and understanding over the last few months.

Daenerys XVI

Chapter Summary

Plans are finalized. Coronation with some unexpected guests with unexpected news.

Chapter Notes

Thank you to justwandering-neverlost for the gorgeous mood board and the beta on this chapter. She's amazeballs. You should all go read everything she writes. Now. This fic can wait.

So, the Coronation scene was written while listening to the song “Marry Me” from Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End Soundtrack. It just builds and builds and it’s beautiful and I love it so much!

Thank you all for the lovely words and feedback. This fic has been a labor of love for over a year and as I grow closer to the end the sadder it makes me. And today marks an official month until the premiere. It's been a long, crazy road and I'm so glad I could share this story with all of you.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

DAENERYS


Yara and Theon had both been summoned to the small council chambers and they were currently waiting on their arrival. Lord Manderly, Davos, Missandei, Varys, and Lady Proudmore were in attendance as well. 


Jon was seated at her side, holding her hand beneath the table. She wanted this to be an acceptable offer to both of them that would keep Yara on her side. Allies in this world were incredibly important to have.


The doors opened and Yara walked into the room, belly bulging more than her own, but only by a little. Carrying two around made her swell faster. Everyone stood and gave nods to Yara who returned them to Jon and Daenerys. The attendants in the room showed her to a chair and Theon pulled it out for her then took his.


Daenerys gave her a smile. “Thank you for coming, Your Grace.”


“Your welcome, Your Grace, ” Yara replied with a smirk. “Are you well? You look about as ready to pop as I am.”


Daenerys rubbed her hand over her belly and sighed. “I’m well. And you?”


“I’ll let you know after this meeting,” she said as she eyed the strangers around the room.


“Queen Yara Greyjoy let me introduce you to our new Mistress of Coin, Lady Justine Proudmore, and our Master of Ships, Lord Waylon Manderly.”


“Manderly? From White Harbor?” He gave her a nod and took a deep breath. “I take it everyone here knows of our agreement?” Yara asked.


Daenerys looked at Lord Manderly and nodded. “They do. And they also know what it is you have asked of the king and I and we believe we have found a solution.” Lord Manderly spread out a map of the North in front of Yara and Theon. “I’ll allow Lord Manderly to tell you the plan.”


He gave a nod and turned to Yara. “Your Grace, we have several empty homesteads since the end of the war with the dead. I have offered to allow Theon to take one while also learning about sailing and shipbuilding and such under my tutelage. He will live in the North and will become a bannerman to Bran Stark should the need ever arise.”


Theon had stood and looked over the map, before turning wary eyes on Dany and Jon. “You’ll do it? You’ll allow me to live there?”


Jon nodded. “Aye. You stayed loyal to the queen, Sansa, and your sister. We believe there’s still some good you can do in this world. We want to give you the opportunity to try.”


Theon turned to Yara who was staring at her brother expectantly. She shrugged. “It’s your choice.”


He looked up at Lord Manderly and held out his hand. “It will be an honor to learn from you.”


Yara smiled at her brother and nodded. “Very well.”


“We will also provide a wet nurse to live with Theon to assure the child is fed,” Jon added.


Yara shook her head. “No need. I made the deal with Theon that if he got what he wanted the Iron Islands would provide anything he needed like that. I may not want this baby, but he does and they shall be provided for by the Greyjoy’s.”


“Whatever you wish,” Daenerys answered and felt a calming peace settle around her shoulders.


*~*


“Your Grace,” Sam called from down the hallway as she was walking to her room with her Unsullied guards. Jon was tending to an issue with Davos regarding the Iron Throne, they were to meet in their chambers for lunch.


She stopped and gave Sam a smile. “Yes, Maester Tarly?”


Sam blushed, eyes darting to the floor. “I’m not technically a maester.”


“Yes, but you saved Jorah from Greyscale, helped settle me after the wildfire, and Jon trusts you to look after me and our daughters, as do I. I don’t think links in a chain make you a maester.” She shook her head. “I’ve distracted you. What can I do for you?”


He held out a scroll. “This came for you while you were in your council meeting.”


It was a raven from Storm’s End. She opened it and smiled as she read its contents. “Good news Your Grace?” Sam asked.


“Indeed. Arya and Gendry are coming for our coronation. Jon will be thrilled to see her, I’m sure.”


He nodded and held out another raven. “And this one, Your Grace.”


She took it and saw the sigil of House Stark. She unrolled the parchment and found the note was from Sansa.


Jon and Daenerys,


Bran has told us of what happened once you reached and took King’s Landing. We here at Winterfell mourn the loss of Tyrion with you. He was always kind to me, one of the smartest people I ever met, and I wish circumstances could have been different. I know Jon has been corresponding with Bran, but I wanted to convey my condolences to the two of you personally.


Stay safe and be well,

Sansa


Sansa was so kind and giving. She gave Sam a polite nod. “Thank you.”


Sam had gone a bit pale in the face as she'd been reading. She raised her brows at him. He cleared his throat, his hands worrying at his side. “Your Grace, I won’t be allowed back to the Citadel. I stole from them and left in the dark of night without permission. I wasn’t even made a Maester, still an apprentice...”


She put a hand on his arm, hoping she could assuage his worries. “Sam, what use do we have of someone from the Citadel when they were such fools they wouldn’t listen to you? You even said the Archmaester said these things were possible, but he ignored them anyway. You are the maester we need. And perhaps we shouldn’t do you the injustice of calling you a maester, seems a paltry title for a man such as yourself.”


Sam blushed from his brow down to his neck. “I’m not as knowledgeable as some of them.”


“You are young, Samwell Tarly. And you are beyond reproach when it comes to the trust that Jon and I have in you. That extends to your wife, Gilly. Your loyalty, above all, would make you worthy in my eyes. But it is your knowledge on a wide range of topics that makes you irreplaceable.” She could see that he was still nervous and sought to calm him further. “Should there be any books that you would like or information, we will do everything in our power to make sure the ability to gain that knowledge comes to you.”


He was silent a moment and nodded his head. “Thank you, Your Grace. I will do whatever it takes to protect and serve your family.”


“And we will do the same for you.”


A smile lit his round face. “Thank you, again.”


She watched him walk down the hall, then turned and made her way into her chamber. A delicious spread of assorted foods laid before her, yet her mind was troubled. Sansa’s raven had caught her off guard. She knew she should write back to her and see how she was fairing. Her good sister had known Tyrion well, and they had become friends in Winterfell. Daenerys was sure his loss was significant to her.


And yet, when she thought of Tyrion her own heart ached. She feared they were doing the wrong things and the kingdom and people would suffer for it. She'd trusted Tyrion to guide them in the right path. Ever since she had proclaimed herself a queen, whether that was as a Khaleesi, or the rightful Queen of the now Six Kingdoms, she had someone at her side to guide her. Jorah, Barristan, Tyrion...each one a brave, intelligent man and each one of them dead.


She fought off the tears as she opened the door to her bedchamber, the gentle squawks of the dragons greeting her. She closed the door and opened the cages, settling each dragon on the floor, watching them chase one another. She smiled as the light blue one curled in front of the fire while Arylion pounced on the green. The green did a roll and knocked Arylion off his back and padded over to the other dragon beside the fire, looking on at the shenanigans of the other two with disdain.


Daenerys went over to the chair beside the fire and picked up the dragon and ran her hand on his scales. “You don’t like being poked and prodded by your siblings, do you? Might even think you’re above it?” She grinned. “Sansax. That’s who you’ll be,” she decreed, bringing the dragon up to her face and nuzzled him. She turned at the shrill squawks coming from the other two dragons as they rolled around and nipped at each other.


She was laughing when Jon entered the room. Arylion darted to him and quickly climbed up his leg with Jon grunting with every press of the talons into his skin. When it was perched on his shoulder, Jon looked both apprehensive and put out. “Will this be routine with you?”


Daenerys nodded and smiled. “I believe it will. It’s fine, now. Wait until they get bigger.”


He rolled his eyes. “Let’s feed them and then we can eat.”


They fed all four of the dragons and continued to allow them to run around the room as they took their seats at the table. “I have news,” she told him.


“Good news, I hope.”


She grinned and took his hand. “Yes. Arya and Gendry are coming for the coronation. They should be here a few days before.”


The smile on his face was one she wanted to remember for the rest of her life. “But his injury...”


“Could you keep Arya in bed when she was injured? I imagine Gendry is much the same.”


He shook his head. “Perhaps the two most stubborn people I’ve ever met.”


“Oh no, my sweet Jon Snow, we are the most stubborn.”


He smirked. “Probably some truth to that.” He suddenly winced and she tilted her head at him. They both looked down to see Arylion ramming his head at his foot. Jon finally picked the little dragon up and held it in front of his face. “You’re being naughty. Taking after your namesake?”


“I can’t wait for Arya to meet them. She’ll be so excited.”


“She does love the dragons.”


“I named the green one Sansax.”


He snorted. “Are you going to name them all before the babies are born?”


“Yes. I want everything done by the time they join us.”


“It will be,” he assured her, reaching over and rubbing her belly. “We have enough people to see to it to help you. Not to mention your husband would like to carry some of the burden for you.”


She gave him a smile. “He’s very good about that.”


*~*


Daenerys was in the small council room waiting for Jaime to arrive. Jon thought it was best to allow her to talk with him as he wasn’t sure he could actually say to the man that he should pursue Sansa.


The door opened and Jaime walked slowly inside. He bowed to her as he stopped in front of her. “Please, have a seat,” she offered. He pulled the chair out but she noticed that his eyes avoided her, instead focused on the table. “How are you fairing?”


“I’m healing well, Your Grace.”


“Good. I asked you here to discuss your future.”


He still didn’t look at her but stared at his golden hand he’d laid upon the table. “Do I have one?”


“I believe so and I think you’ll agree once you hear what I have to say.” Jaime swallowed thickly but nodded. She went straight to the point. “At our coronation, we will recognize you for your efforts during the war against the dead and the march south.” She stood and paced closer to him and sat in the chair beside him. “We will acknowledge what you did to Bran. For that, Jon and Bran have agreed that your punishment is to be banned from the North for the entirety of your life.”


She allowed that a moment to sink in before she continued. “But, as Lady Brienne told us when you first arrived at Winterfell, you are not the man you were. You came to help us when you didn’t have to. You served the realm by protecting it from evil. That is a large debt. You also saved Sansa’s life. Another debt. You saved my life,” she said with a smile. “You fought with Jon against your bannermen in Harrenhall and you kept your word and eliminated your sister under dire circumstances,” she whispered the last part, trying to hold herself together. Mentioning Tyrion usually brought her to tears. “For those good deeds, and the many that came before it, we are going to restore all your titles and land and make you Warden of the West at Casterly Rock.”


He finally looked up at her then, confusion clearly written on his face. “My family sought to destroy the Targaryens and the Starks. I nearly killed a little boy—”


“I know,” she cut over him. “And you have your punishment for that. But the truth is, Jaime, you’ve lived your life all these years at the whims of other people. You served a king you hated, you served your sister, you have done nothing but serve since you were a boy. You will serve Jon and I as our Warden but we both feel you can do more in this life than serve as a guard. You stand in a position to help people. You’ve also been doing that since you were a boy,” she acknowledged.


“And what does the king think of this?”


She smiled. “Jon is the one who told the small council yesterday that this was what he wanted for you. The three of us share the burden of loss. Parents, siblings, and friends. Circumstances being what they are, you have acted with honor since I’ve met you.” She tilted her head. “Surviving people you love, especially when you feel you could have prevented their death, is a hard burden to carry. The King and I both share that burden with you.”


Jaime shook his head. “I don’t know anything about running a Keep. I ignored those lessons—”


“I have a solution for that,” she interrupted him, biting back a grin. “Find a proper lady to marry. One with experience in running a Keep. From a Great House. Someone who can share in your loss and your love.”


His eyes shifted back to the table. “I don’t deserve her.”


She let her smile go free. “No one does. But perhaps you should consult her about that before you make any decisions.”


“She told me goodbye and she meant it.”


“She probably did, at that moment. But how will you ever know unless you ask?”


She put a hand over her stomach and winced. Jaime leaned forward in concern. “Are you alright?”


She nodded. “Yes. Just took a foot to my ribs,” she grumbled. “After our coronation, you and the remainder of the Lannister army will return back to your homes. We ask that you pledge your sword and house to us at the coronation after we restore your lands and titles.”


He shook his head. “It’s more than I deserve.”


“Then earn it every day by being a good Lord to your people. I believe in you. Tyrion did, as well. And as he often told me, he was an excellent judge of character.”


*~*


One month later


Jon huffed out a breath as he looked down at the white leather tunic. “Why white? Why not red and black?”


“White breeds hope,” she said as Missandei helped lace her dress. As it was their coronation day, Daenerys had told her friend that she could get a handmaiden to help her dress, but her friend had refused. “It’s a fresh, new spring.”


A knock came at the door and Jon called for them to enter. It was Davos, looking as clean in white as the rest of them. She had even had made a white pouch for his fingers. His smile had been bright when she’d presented him the clothes. “You both look regal and pure,” he greeted them.


Daenerys put her hands on her large round belly. “Pure as the driven snow, in my case.”


“You look radiant, Your Grace.” He turned to Jon. “Your sister has just arrived.”


Her husband's face lit with joy. “Where is she?”


“She asked for a room to freshen up and said she’ll see you at your crowning.”


Jon scowled at that. “Did she say what delayed them?”


Davos shook his head. “When I asked everyone grew quiet. I imagine she’ll tell you when you speak.”


Jon heaved a sigh. “I hate secrets.”


“So do I,” Daenerys said as Missandei finally finished.


She did a quick spin and Missandei gave a small laugh. “You look beautiful.”


“As do you, my friend. How much longer?”


“Less than an hour, Your Grace.”


“Very good. Has the hall filled?”


“To capacity. And the people have gathered outside in celebration as well. The Unsullied and Dothraki are ready to keep the peace should we have any problems, but we don’t expect any.”


“Wonderful,” she said as she smoothed her gown over her belly. She knew their girls would be here soon, she would be able to hold them in her arms and give them all the love she had. She also knew she would miss having them inside her, moving around, growing. She closed her eyes against the tears that were threatening. She had to be strong today, keep it together.


This was the culmination of her hard work, everything she suffered was for this moment, to take the throne with the love of her life at her side. She looked at Jon and found him staring at her with a small smile on his face.


“Are we ready?”


“Yes, Your Grace.”


*~*


Behind the closed doors of the throne room, Jon took her hand and placed a kiss on the back of it. “I love you.”


She smiled at him. “I love you, too. Now, don’t make me cry before we go in there,” she warned.


He held her hand in his and faced the doors. She took a deep breath as she heard the doors open and she and Jon took their steps into the throne room side by side. She wished she still had her hair. It would have been wrapped in a series of braids and swirls. Her first crown. But she would wear the other with pride. The two thrones that sat at the front were comfortable, as they had spent an entire day trying out possible choices. She thought that if anything felt remotely comfortable while she was pregnant then anything would work when she wasn’t.


She took note of the windows and almost smiled to see the center of the windows, not with the Targaryen symbol, which was customary in the past, but a map of the kingdoms. Theirs would be a world united, not one divided by houses.


They took the steps up and stood in front of their people, facing them. She surveyed their expectant expressions.


Jaime, dressed in red and gold, stood beside the Hound. His ear had healed, his hair hiding the scars. He towered over the rest of the people. Robin Aryn along with his guard stood at his side. The young man looked too happy to be amongst those in attendance. She knew that part of it was that he was going to get another ride on the dragon. She would allow Jon to take him up, this time. 


Arya and Gendry were on the left side of the aisle, both wearing bright smiles. To her surprise, Arya was wearing a dress, her hair pulled into a single braid at the back. While her dress wasn’t the same color as Gendry’s fine tunic and cloak, they did go together. She had her sword and knife strapped to her side, which nearly caused Dany to smile. Yara and Theon were to their left. Her coronation would be after she returned to the Iron Islands. Daenerys had promised she would do everything in her power to attend, and if she couldn’t, she would send Jon in her place.


Lord Manderly and his wife were beside Theon, the young man taking on well with his new Lord. Yara appeared to like Lord Manderly as well.


Then Davos came forward and her heart tumbled with pride as he placed the crown on Jon’s head. “I present to you, King Aegon of Houses Stark and Targaryen, Sixth Of His Name, Friend to the Free Folk, Lord Commander of The Night's Watch, The Undead, and Hero for the Dawn.”


She couldn’t hide her smile. Jon's fingers squeezed hers tighter and she took a deep breath as Davos then stepped in front of her. He gently placed her own crown atop her head. The weight of the metal against her still short hair was comforting somehow. “And Queen Daenerys Stormborn of House Targaryen, First of Her Name, Khaleesi of the Great Grass Sea, The Unburnt, the Mother of Dragons, the Breaker of Chains, and Hero for the Dawn.”


They took their seats on their respective thrones as Ser Davos called out, “Long may they reign.”


The room filled with a chorus of voices. “Long may they reign.”


They took a few moments to allow the moment to settle over the crowd as the women curtseyed and the men bowed. Jon looked at her and gave her a nod once things had calmed. “Ser Jaime Lannister, please step forward,” she summoned.


A murmur fell over the crowd as Jaime stood in the middle of the aisle. “If this world has taught us anything it is that people are capable of great change. You served my father as his King’s Guard. You served my mother and my brother. You served the realm. But great men can make great mistakes.”


“You pushed my brother, the Warden of the North, Brandon Stark from a tower when he was a boy and left him a cripple.” Jon’s voice was stern and still held anger over the actions, but he was disciplined in his delivery. “For this, you are banished from the North for the rest of your life. Should you break this law, you will be dealt with by the Warden of the North.”


The grumbling grew louder and Daenerys spoke. “But as I said, men are capable of great change. You saved the life of the Wardeness of the North, Sansa Stark. You rode to the aid of the living after your sister betrayed her word. You fought bravely, saving the life of Lady Brienne of Tarth during the battle for Winterfell. You saved my life at the Battle of the Twins. You fought bravely beside the King inside Harrenhal. You dispatched Cersei Lannister from her place upon this throne.” She took a deep breath. “For this, we restore all your titles and lands. You are also to be named our Warden of the West, to keep peace and protect your people.”


Jaime withdrew his sword and knelt in front of them. “I, Jaime Lannister, pledge my house and my life to House Targaryen, for all nights to come.”


“Rise, Lord Jaime,” Jon bid. “Serve us well.”


He stepped back into the crowd. “The crown also recognizes Queen Yara Greyjoy of the Iron Islands for her dedication to House Targaryen during the wars. With our pact, Queen Yara has agreed that the Iron Islands will become an independent country, an ally to ours, and come to our aid should enemies attack. We will honor the same pact,” Daenerys said with a nod at Yara who bowed her head in response.


Jon spoke next. “It is with glad, but heavy hearts, that we sit upon these thrones. So many of our friends and companions have died to see us here. We recognize their loss and acknowledge them with the call of the dragons.”


A great shadow flew by the large windows as Drogon called out first, followed by Rhaegal.


Daenerys sat back in her seat, a swelling of accomplishment washing over her. But, as she glanced to her left, she felt the absence of Tyrion in her heart. She nearly wept, knowing that this is what they had been working towards for years and he wasn’t there to see it. No, he sees it all. We sent him to the stars to sit in judgment upon us. He is here.


*~*


Once at the feast, the wine was flowing, food was being eaten, and someone had called for her to have a dance with her husband. It had only been taught to them the week before, as neither had training in dance. She was flushed and out of breath too easily these days. She was walking to her seat when Yara intercepted her. “Your Grace,” she said with a nod of her head.


“Your Grace,” she smiled at her. “How are you?”


“Ready to get this baby out of me. Other than that, I’m fine. I think you will find the crowning ceremony for the Iron Islands to be a little different.”


She nodded. “I’ve heard. But I will do everything in my power to be there, I assure you.”


“I believe you. Thank you for what you’ve done for Theon. For the first time since I’ve known him, he seems at peace.”


“I’m glad. Are you?”


She nodded. “Yes. I believe our two kingdoms will have to work together to get the Iron Islands used to not reaping and reaving.”


“I know. And as we are both reasonable women, I’m sure we can come to an agreement that is beneficial to one another.”


“I know we will. Enjoy your feast, Your Grace. You’ve earned it.”


Daenerys watched her disappear into the crowd and found Jon seated with Arya and Gendry. Jon looked up at her with a smile and held out his hand as he stood. He helped her to her seat and took his beside her. “I’m so glad you two could come,” she greeted the pair.


“Wouldn’t miss it for the world,” Gendry said.


“Everything settled in Storm’s End?”


Arya nodded. “I sent Bran a raven asking before we left. He assured us that the Keep was safe with Lord Farring and that the Faceless Men had taken our payment. How are you, sister?” Arya asked with a smile.


“Tired,” she laughed. “But so very happy.”


Jon nodded. “Tell her.”


Arya wrinkled her nose and looked at Gendry. He nodded at her and sighed. “One of the reasons we’re here is that we were hoping we could use your Godswood.”


“Is there not one in Storm’s End?”


“It was burnt,” Arya said with distaste.


“The Godswood is yours if you need it. For what purpose?”


“We’re looking to get married,” Gendry announced, his smile uncontained.


Daenerys grinned. “Truly betrothed now?”


Arya nodded. “There’s a lot to talk about, but yes. We’re getting married.”


“When?”


“Soon. We were hoping Ser Davos would do the ceremony part and Jon could give me away.”


Daenerys smiled as Jon nodded and pulled his sister into his side, placing a kiss to her hair.  “It would be my honor,” he whispered.


Arya turned away and Daenerys would swear she could see tears in her eyes. She cleared her throat as she scanned the crowd. “How long until Jaime asks for Sansa?”


Jon shook his head. “He hasn’t yet, that we know of.”


“He feels he doesn’t deserve her.”


“He doesn’t,” Arya and Jon answered at the same time. But Arya continued. “But that’s not for us to decide. It’s always been up to her.”


“And do you think she’ll go?” Gendry asked. “She’d be leaving Winterfell and I always got the impression she was against that.”


“She was,” Jon answered.


Daenerys shrugged. “It would be a hard decision for her, I’m sure. But I think we can all agree that whatever was between them is not gone.”


Arya shook her head. “She writes me often. She usually finds a way to mention him at least once in each letter.”


“It’s her decision,” Jon declared. “Will you be going to Bran’s wedding?”


“We’ll leave here in a few days and start North.”


“Why don’t you take one of our ships? You’ll get there faster and have longer to visit. Then when you come back South, you can stop here and we can have a longer visit.”


Arya smiled. “That’s kind of you. We’ll take you up on that offer. Will you be attending his wedding?”


“Just Jon and only for a day or two. Twins usually come early, so...”


“Will you be having the babies here?"

 

“No. Dragonstone. Ser Davos will be in our place while we’re gone. Missandei will be with me.”


“And I’m sure Jon could have Bran take a look home if he grows worried about you.”


“Oh, I will,” Jon declared. “Faster than ravens is the three-eyed raven.”


They all chuckled. “Don’t bother him too much. It will be his wedding, after all.”


“I’m taking Rhaegal. Drogon will be on Dragonstone with Daenerys.”


Daenerys smiled. “There is something I want to show you later, Arya. Once the feast has died down, I hope you will walk back with me to our chamber.”


“Of course.”


*~*


Daenerys was glad she had Arya with her as she walked back to her room. She was exhausted and looked forward to a bath as well as sleeping beside her husband in their bed.


The door was opened by her guard and she walked inside with Arya following behind. “I don’t know how much Bran has told you, but I think there is someone you should meet.” Daenerys opened the little cages and let out each dragon. Arya’s eyes widened as they circled around her feet.


“More dragons,” she said in awe, with a small laugh. She knelt down and the purple one immediately tried to climb up her body. It nipped at her fingers and she finally picked it up. “Amazing.”


“It’s funny that should be the one that climbs onto you.”


“Why funny?”


“Because of its name. Arylion.”


She looked up at Daenerys with surprise. “You named a dragon after me?”


She nodded and picked up the green. “And this is Sansax.”


She chuckled. “And Sansa. What about the other two?”


“Well, they don’t have names yet.”


“What about your own babies? Do they have names?”


“Rhaella and Lyanna.”


Arya gave a small smile. “After your mothers. A lovely tribute.”


Daenerys saw how nervous she suddenly seemed and that caused her to tilt her own head in concern. “Are you alright?”


She heaved a sigh and stroked the dragon in her hands. “Yes, just an unexpected complication.”


“What’s that?”


“When the Faceless Men attacked, they tried to poison me with moon tea. I drank it because I didn’t want to get pregnant. But with the attack, the maester had it all discarded and it slipped my mind...”


“Are you pregnant?” Daenerys asked, more surprised than she could be about anything else Arya could have said.


She nodded. “At least, we think I am. My moon blood hasn’t come, I was sick nearly every morning during our travels which is what delayed us a few days, I’m constantly tired...”


Daenerys was stunned but happy for her. “Does Jon know?”


She bit her lip. “Gendry wanted to tell him, privately. We agreed to do it while I escorted you here.”


The door suddenly opened and Jon entered the room followed by Gendry, both wearing smiles. Arya stood and Jon wrapped his arms around her. “I can’t believe this.”


She chuckled. “No one was more surprised than me.”


He pulled away from her and cupped her face. “It seems like just yesterday I gave you Needle and...”


“Well, when you think about it, we missed years with one another. We haven’t had much time since.”


“Are you well? Do you need anything?”


Arya looked at Gendry who was standing nearby. She shook her head. “No. Just the Godswood.”


“Is that why you’re getting married?”


She shook her head and stepped away from Jon and toward her betrothed. “No. He asked before we knew and I said ‘yes’. The baby is perhaps pushing it forward a bit.”


“What will you tell those at Storm’s End?”


“We’ve already made the announcement that we were going to get married while we were away as I recognize the Old Gods and there was no Godswood. I want to have a ceremony to honor my father.”


“You could wait until you get to Winterfell. Get married there,” Jon suggested.


Arya nodded. “We could. But I think given current circumstances that the sooner the better. The men that traveled with us already know about Gendry and me, but Lord Farring cautioned that traveling through the rest of the country, again, without us being married might send a bad message. While I don’t necessarily care about me, I care for my child.”


Daenerys put a hand on her arm. “We could always kill anyone that spoke ill of you or your child.”


Arya laughed a bit. “I made that same suggestion but Gendry thought it would earn a bad reputation if we just started killing people because they spoke ill of us.”


“Wise,” Jon said with a stern look at his sister.


“I’ll remind you that your wife just made the same suggestion I did.”


Daenerys shrugged. “I’m in such an emotional state I can’t recall saying anything of the like.” They all stared at her, Jon with a slight smirk on his face. “Claiming that you’re pregnant and highly emotional could work to your advantage.”


“I’ll keep that in mind.”


Gendry frowned. “Great. I don’t lose enough arguments with her as it is.”


“Prepare to lose them all, now,” Jon said as he clapped him on the back.


*~*


Daenerys settled the pillow beneath her belly. Jon was already partially dozing beside her and so she tried to be as stealthy as she could to not wake him. He’d been working doubly hard the last week and deserved as much rest as he could get. She finally settled, one pillow between her knees, another beneath her stomach and two beneath her head and she finally felt the stresses of the day melting into the mattress.


She felt a warm hand cup her hip and a kiss on her shoulder. “I must have dozed off.”


“You did, but you earned it.”


“I have a feeling we’ve only begun to be tired,” he whispered.


“Between running the kingdom, baby dragons, big dragons, and babies of our own I’m positive that you’re right. But we earned all of it, didn’t we? We’ve suffered and paid prices that we often felt were too high. Yet, here we lay, the new King and Queen of Westeros.”


He had his lips pressed against her shoulder. “I don’t feel like I earned you or the happiness you’ve brought into my life. That, I don’t think, I’ll ever deserve.”


“Jon, don’t make me roll over and hit you. I’ve only just gotten comfortable.”


He chuckled. “I’m allowed to doubt how any of this became possible. I grew up a bastard and now I’m not only married to the most beautiful woman the gods ever created, but she’s having my babies, she’s brought dragons into the world, and we’re the king and queen of millions of people. How did this become my life?”


“You earned it, my love. You earned my love by being the lovely man that you are.”


“I love you, Daenerys. You have to know that I realize how lucky I am to have you.”


“I feel the same way about you, Jon. The love of my life.”


“My queen. Long may she reign.”

Chapter End Notes

Jaime is next. I've already started on it and hope to have it finished soon.

Let me know what you think and I hope you enjoy the chapter. I'm trying to respond to all comments and questions.

Jamie XV

Chapter Summary

Jaime returns to Casterly Rock and makes a decision about his future while confronting the past.

Chapter Notes

Thank you to justwanderingneverlost for the gorgeous mood board. She's so damn good.

I hope you guys like this chapter.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

JAIME

 

Jamie,

 

I hope this raven finds you recovering well from your wound. Bran told me of the knife. He also told me about Tyrion. It is with such a heavy heart I offer you my condolences. Your brother was always so kind to me, even at times when he probably shouldn’t have been.

 

I know all too well the pain of losing a beloved sibling. I know how much Tyrion meant to you but I also know how much you meant to him. You were his hero in every sense of the word. He loved you without reason and without expectation. That is something to be treasured and I know you do.

 

Through these dark times, I only hope you can find light again.

 

Lady Sansa Stark

Lady of Winterfell

Wardeness of the North

 

He rolled up the parchment again, feeling his chest ache as he read it for the hundredth time since he'd received it a few short weeks ago. Leave it to her to be able to render him speechless.

 

He had promised he would stay for their coronation and do their bidding, but he wanted to leave the Red Keep as soon as possible, and the following morning he had all of his items packed, had prepared the men, and they would march West toward his family seat.

 

He grabbed up his final rucksack and tucked Sansa’s note into his pocket, close to him so he was still able to have it with him. He made his way out to the waiting caravan and was surprised to find the king and queen waiting on him as well.

 

“I didn’t realize you would be leaving so soon,” Daenerys said softly.

 

“No sense in dwelling here.”

 

“Be safe on your ride.”

 

“Safe as I can be.” He looked at the two of them. Daenerys wearing one of her more structured grey dresses with red embellishments and the Targaryen chain draped across her chest. Her hair was beginning to grow back in, though still short, she looked no less than a queen. It struck him then how much she favored her mother and looked away guiltily. Another person in his life he had failed to protect.

 

Jon, while he wasn't scowling at him, did look troubled. “Thank you for all you did during the war and after. I will make sure people know you conducted yourself with honor and will cause problems for anyone who dares say the word Kingslayer or Oathbreaker in regards to you.”

 

Jaime shook his head, confused by his opinion changing so drastically. “I don’t feel I deserve that sort of defense, Your Grace.”

 

Jon looked at Daenerys then back at Jaime. “You saved my wife’s life. That’s a debt I don’t think I can ever repay. But I also know that it was you who kept me from going into the Wildfire that day to get to her. You rounded up the soldiers, you who kept his word and did something I don’t know if I would have the strength to do,” he said softly. “And I know that Tyrion was honest with people whether they liked what he had to say. He thought the world of you. I know what it’s like to lose a brother, see one die in front of me and feel like I could have prevented it. I wish we didn’t have that in common,” Jon went on. “With all of that, the things you’ve done and how you’ve changed, I know that we’ve put our faith in the right man.”

 

He swallowed the lump in his throat. “Thank you, Your Grace.”

 

“Oh,” Daenerys said suddenly. “There is one more thing.” She walked over to one of the attendants and opened the cage to show him one of the baby dragons. This one was ice blue, reminding him of the dead dragon they fought during the War for the Dawn. “I wanted you to see them,” she admitted. “At least one. One of them is too rambunctious to bring out to see other people,” she said with a laugh. “Lord Jaime, I am pleased to introduce you to Tyrionous.”

 

He looked up at her shocked, finding it hard to see her through his tears. “You named a dragon after him?”

 

She nodded and smiled. “Yes. He once told me how he loved dragons as a child and had asked for one. I only hate that it was after his passing that they were born. He helped bring them into the world, it's only fair that his memory lives on with them.”

 

Jaime shook his head. “I continue to be amazed by the both of you, and as a cynical man, that’s surprising. Thank you for allowing me to return to Casterly Rock.”

 

Jon nodded. “It’s your ancestral home. I hope that from now on the Targaryens, the Starks, and the Lannisters can be true allies.”

 

“I will honor my vow made to you.”

 

“And your children after you,” Daenerys said with a nod. “Have you...decided on a suitable bride?”

 

He smirked and climbed atop his horse. “Perhaps. If she’ll have me. She’s rather stubborn in her own right.”

 

Daenerys smiled as she cradled the dragon in her arms. It looked natural, like a mother holding her babe. Mother of dragons. “Be well, my queen. I’m sure the princesses will be quite the handful.”

 

“I know they will. Safe journey. Please let us know when you arrive in Casterly Rock.”

 

He nodded. “I will.” He looked at Jon and bowed his head. “I do wish I still had my hand. It would have been interesting to see how I faired.”

 

“Is he the best you’ve ever seen?” Daenerys asked with a smile and nudged her husband with her elbow. He did not look thrilled at the teasing.

 

“He’s close. Ser Arthur Dayne was the best I ever saw. But he would be in the running,” he said with a smile. “When we meet again, I’ll tell you all about the fight that lasted nearly all day between Arthur Dayne and Barristan Selmy.”

 

“I look forward to it,” Daenerys admitted and even Jon nodded.

 

The king stepped forward and rubbed the nose of the horse. “Be safe, travel fast, and if you decide to marry Sansa, know that I’ll have Brienne send me pieces of you in boxes so each one is a gift to myself should you hurt her.”

 

Jaime’s eyes widened. “I would sooner try to eat Drogon alive than hurt Sansa.”

 

He nodded. “Be well, Lord Jaime.”

 

*~*

 

Later that night, once he was situated in his tent alone, he thought of how different his world was, now. For the better part of his life, he had lived in the capital. His job had always been to protect the king or queen, his sister, his father, his children. But that was gone. He didn’t know what to do about such a drastic difference. Fighting, protecting, even running was more familiar to him at this point than living in his family’s ancestral home, taking care of its people and land. He didn’t know how to do that.

 

He looked at the nub where his hand had been, feeling its loss keenly in the late night. He was serviceable with a sword, now. No one would ever call him great. But he had been once. He had been a lot of things that he wasn’t any longer. He had never been an honest lord. He had saved a million lives when he killed the Mad King. Probably more when he killed Cersei. But how would he provide for those around him? He knew the mines were dried up from conversations with his sister. How would he be able to help his people?

 

He wondered if this was the king and queen’s ultimate revenge on him, to send him to do a job he didn’t know how to do. Send him to the Rock and let him waste away, unable to hurt anyone. He supposed that if he didn’t do a good job, they’d remove him from power. They certainly had the army and dragons to do so.

 

His mind wandered to the small dragon he had seen today. Tyrionous . How thrilled his brother would have been. He remembered when they were younger and how he had often talked about having one of his own, a small one like him, and how he had found his brother crying when he learned that dragons were gone from the world. What must Tyrion have thought when he first saw the dragons? Was that what had pushed him to side with Daenerys?

 

He knew the truth. He sided with Daenerys because she was a ruler that cared about people. She had in her council a host of people that weren’t Lords or Ladies of the elite class. They were a mixture of people and because of that, she understood the plight of the common folk. It's why she was so beloved. Why Cersei was so hated. She didn’t care about others. She had only ever cared about him and her children. Her affection for him had waned over time and turned to something bitter and hateful. The death of Tommen should have told him that she was different, not the woman he had loved all those years. He never saw her shed a tear for his death, instead, she said he betrayed her.

 

He saw the note poking from the pocket of his jerkin. He grasped it in his good hand and unrolled it, looking upon the pretty writing on the parchment. That one roll held hope for his future. At least, he wanted it to. He thought about writing her over and over again since he received it. He wanted to thank her for her concern. Thank her for being someone who cared about him in a world where he felt so alone.

 

But he hadn’t. Fear stilled his hand every time, too afraid to find out if it was just a friendly gesture and she really was done with him. He lived with the knowledge that he could find out, any day, that she was engaged to some Northern lord who would use her for her title. Would that man hurt her like she had been hurt in the past? Surely her brother would be able to see a horrible man like that and warn her away. He still feared it for her. Brienne would take the head of anyone who hurt her. He knew that. No, Sansa was probably truly safe for the first time in years.

 

He closed his eyes, feeling like it was useless to wonder. Daenerys and Jon had both encouraged him to at least try, but the fear of having her reject him stilled his hand. But fear had kept him from acting with honor in the past. If anyone deserved for him to behave with honor, it was Sansa. He finally sat up and rummaged through his rucksack for parchment and a quill. He found a parchment. The quill he found had a broken nib, and so he stood and walked to the opening of his tent and found two of the Lannister men outside. “Find me a quill and ink. I also need a courier.”

 

Within minutes, he had both and sat staring at the blank page, wondering what he would say. He closed his eyes and saw her red hair and blue eyes. She was smiling back at him as she held her sword aloft in an advance.

 

He smiled.

 

Lady Sansa Stark,

 

I want to apologize for taking so long to respond to your letter. I don’t have a better explanation than to say that I didn’t have the words to express what I was feeling. Even a moon removed from the events and I can’t wrap my head around any of it, to be honest. We are always honest with each other.

 

Watching Tyrion die was one of the worst moments of my life. He had come to the Keep to prevent me from doing what was to be so difficult for me to do. And it was. Even after I watched her kill him, it always seems like it was someone else who killed her. Grief can make us do terrible things, as can fear.

 

Fear is what has stilled my hands all these weeks. I want so much to be someone who deserves you, but I’m not. However, I am selfish and I’m used to taking and getting what I want. That isn’t to say that I feel that you’ll come running at this letter. If anything, I wouldn’t blame you if you burned it upon reading. As I’m being honest, I should tell you that I love you. It feels natural to say it. Like it is equally the easiest and hardest thing I’ve ever said to someone. I don’t deserve your love. I don’t deserve you. I never will. But I swear upon what little honor I have that I will spend the rest of my days trying. I will try to be the man you deserve.

 

I wish I could be there to tell you this in person. I’m sure you know that I can not ever return to the North, and must, therefore, rely on this message getting to you through a courier, but I would ask you to marry me. I should probably ask you properly, but I’m not actually a proper gentleman, am I?

 

I’m rambling. I love you, Sansa, and I want you to be my wife. Should you refuse, I will accept it as graciously as I can. I’ll probably take up drinking. Wallow away on the Rock and allow my house to die out with as little dignity as I can muster. But if you accept, I will welcome you and anyone who comes with you. Put me out of my misery, my lady, and return to the courier with your answer.

 

All my love,

Jaime

 

He stared at it and shook his head. He knew he would chicken out if he didn’t get it out of his hands immediately. He rolled it up and found his seal within his trunk. The longer it took the wax to melt, the more tempted he was to tear the parchment apart and start over. But as he poured it and sealed it with the lion of House Lannister, he heaved a deep breath. He wasn’t going to break the seal.

 

He opened up the flap of his tent and found the courier standing outside. “Take this to Winterfell, to Lady Sansa Stark. You’re to wait for an answer, be it verbal or written,” he held up a pouch of dragons. “I’ll give you another when you meet us at Casterly Rock with the answer.”

 

“Yes m’lord,” the man said as he tucked the parchment into his sack. He climbed on his horse and rode off into the night. He heaved a deep breath and went back into the tent and lay back upon his bedroll once more. He closed his eyes and rubbed his hand over his face, feeling anxiety and hope all in one. It would probably be in her best interest to deny him, but he hoped that she would accept.

 

His sleep that evening was fitful and consisted of bright blue eyes and flaming red hair. How he hoped to see her face, again.

 

*~*

 

Their arrival at Casterly Rock had been met with the staff of the keep waiting in the courtyard. He dismounted from his horse and found a man he didn’t recognize approach. “Lord Jaime, welcome home.”

 

“Thank you. You are?”

 

“Lucion Lannister, my lord. My father, Damion, had been named castellan some years ago by your sister. He trained me in what was needed to run the keep before he passed.”

 

Jaime nodded. “Yes, I remember Damion,” he said as he watched several of the men around him dismount. “These men have ridden hard. See to it they have rooms and a feast prepared for them. They fought well when asked.”

 

“Yes, My Lord. We’ve had your chambers dressed for you,” he said as he walked beside Jaime through the halls of Casterly Rock. The place still smelled the same. He hadn’t been there since before they sacked Highgarden. It amazed him how smells could bring back memories better than any of the other senses. He could almost smell his mother as he walked through the halls. “We also laid your sister in the crypts beside your mother.”

 

He stopped walking and looked at Damion. “Thank you. Don’t mention her from this moment forward.”

 

“My Lord?”

 

“My sister was a mad, evil woman. The less I have to hear about her, the better I think everyone would get along,” he said as he started walking again. Damion caught up with him quickly and led him to the Lord’s chamber. His father’s room. He opened the doors and looked around, finding it reminded him too much of the family he had lost.

 

“Tomorrow, Lucion, we will go over the ledgers and you will tell me how issues regarding Lannisport are being handled.”

 

“Yes, my Lord. Shall I have a bath run for you?”

 

“Yes. And I’ll take supper in my room. Don’t disturb me unless a courier comes for me.”

 

“Of course.”

 

Jaime watched the man leave and close the doors behind him. He walked out to the balcony and stared out at the setting sun over the water. He hung his head, fighting off tears at the thought of all he had lost. He remembered being a young boy and coming into this room to have his mother tell him stories of knights and fair maidens. He remembered coming to her bedside when she died the day Tyrion was born.

 

He had lost his mother but gained a brother. Cersei never forgave Tyrion for the act of being born. Was that the first sign of her madness? How could anyone blame a child for being born? His mother fought to bring Tyrion into the world, gave her life for it, and for that Jaime could never hate his brother. He felt protective of him, knowing that Cersei didn’t care that he was a baby and would wreak havoc on him if not watched. He felt like that truly started the bond he felt with his brother.

 

As Tyrion grew older, he saw that even his father resented that he’d been born and their mother had died. He felt it was his duty as the older brother to protect him. Sometimes, when they would play, he could pretend it was just them, getting lost in games. Cersei hated this and was jealous. She would then take her wrath out on Tyrion if she could, the household staff if not. He wondered how much she did to him that Jaime hadn’t seen?

 

He shook his head and turned away from the fading sun. A maid came in and lit the braziers as he heard a bath being drawn in the adjoining room. Food was brought in and settled on the table as well as wine. The servants left him as he ate from the platter in front of him and drank all the wine that was in the room. He was told shortly after that his bath was ready. He sent them away as he removed the hand that had been made for him and placed it on the table beside his bed.

 

He settled back into the hot water, almost finding it too hot, but rested back and stared at the vaulted ceiling. He’d never felt so alone in his life. He was in his family keep with people he didn’t know. It had been nearly a full moon since he’d sent the courier on his way and yet he’d had no word as to whether the man had even reached Winterfell.

 

He could picture her in the snow, with white flakes scattered in her bright hair. He brushed his hand over his brow. He was driving himself mad, wondering what her response would be. He longed to see her face, to hear her voice, her laugh. Anything was better than the torment of not knowing for sure what his fate would be.

 

When he climbed into bed that night, he found sleep a difficult thing to grasp, but once he had it, he fell into a fitful sleep where shocked green eyes stared helplessly at him, then the bulging eyes of his sister, and all too soon, the harsh judging eyes of his father.

 

*~*

 

Morning light spilled into the room as a knock sounded at the door. He bid the person enter, hoping it was the courier. A figure entered, a hood covering their face and he felt fear in his chest.

 

She removed the hood and his heart sped to see Sansa, a bright smile on her face as she dropped her cape to reveal nothing underneath. She crossed the room and joined him in bed, her lips finding his in a heated kiss that caused him to tingle to his toes. “You’re here,” he whispered.

 

“Where else would I be?”

 

He shook his head. “I don’t deserve you.”

 

“Stop feeling sorry for yourself,” she admonished. “You’re the Lord of a Keep. It’s time you take care of other people through your direct actions. Let them see the man I see,” she whispered before she kissed him again. He sat up, both arms wrapped around her. “The man I love.”

 

“Do you? Love me?”

 

“Would I be here if I didn’t?”

 

He shook his head. “Too much talking,” he said and then he was inside her. She was beneath him, her body wrapped around him as she gasped his name. He shivered at the dig of her nails in his flesh. She was perfect. He came soon after, then felt a pain in his side. He rolled to his back and was horrified to watch Sansa holding up a bloody dagger. Her face and hair changed. She was no longer his ginger beauty but his mad sister, her lips curled in a sneer.

 

“I told you no one walks away from me.”

 

He jolted awake, his side aching, his sheets wet, and tears streaming down his face. He wondered if it was him that was going mad.

 

*~*

 

A week later and he had started to pick up on the parts of running a keep that he had missed. He had sent the soldiers who had traveled back to Casterly Rock with him home to be with their families. Just because his was gone didn’t mean they had to stay away from theirs.

 

He had just returned from meeting with some of the people in town when he was told a lone rider approached from the North. He went to the rampart and realized it was the courier. He quickly went to the yard and when the man entered and dismounted, Jaime could see that he was exhausted. The man held out a letter sealed with the Stark dire wolf.

 

Jaime instructed that the man be given a pouch of dragons and left them all staring after him. He went into his room and to the balcony. He poured a glass of wine and drank it all down before he broke the seal.

 

Jaime,

 

I am sorry for your punishment. It would have been nice to walk through the Godswood with you, once more. I had been waiting, impatiently, to receive a response from you and feared that I would get none. I thought I might have ruined what could have been a happy future when I told you goodbye. Relief was not the only emotion I felt when your courier arrived.

 

Your letter has eased my heart and mind. I feared I might have been more taken with you, but to see that was not the case warmed me. You bewitched me. By all rights, I should despise you, but I can’t nor will I. I love you. I accept your proposal. I would love nothing more than to be your wife.

 

My brother marries in a few short days, which will have passed by the time you read this. I have promised him that I will stay for one week after his wedding and then travel to take my place at your side. I bring an assortment of different people with me. I hope the people there will take kindly to Wildlings amongst my companions. Tormund, Brienne, his two daughters, and I also have two Wildling females as my other guard. Podrick has been knighted and serves as Bran’s sworn sword. We should arrive within two weeks of your courier. Tormund has asked that I tell you he expects a feast for his arrival.

 

I have missed you and hope we can marry soon. Perhaps two days after I arrive? I assume you have a sept. My mother worshiped the faith of the seven, and as my last Godswood wedding ended in horror for me, I wish to not have anything resembling that when I pledge to be your wife.

 

I will see you soon, to love you with all my heart,

Sansa

 

Jaime sat in the chair and read it again and again. He took several deep breaths then started laughing. He tucked the note into his pocket and stormed from the room and began barking orders to have rooms made up and the sept cleared, cleaned, and polished for a wedding.

 

“A wedding, my Lord?”

 

“Yes, my betrothed will arrive in a few weeks times and we will marry two days after she arrives.”

 

“That’s wonderful news, my Lord.”

 

He smiled at Lucion. “It is. We’ll also have rooms made for those that travel with her. A family consisting of a man, woman, and two children, and two female guards.”

 

“Female guards?” Lucion questioned.

 

Jaime looked at him. “My bride to be is no ordinary woman. Her sworn sword is one of the best fighters I’ve ever seen, and she’s a woman. This woman’s husband commanded Wildlings and is one himself. Her other two guards, women, also Wildlings. If anyone takes issue with any of that, tell them they can take it up with me.”

 

“Yes, my Lord. A feast and rooms.”

 

“Nice rooms with good linens. I want my sister's room completely redone.”

 

“What would you have?”

 

“Remove the bed, all the linens. Put a desk facing the door with a comfortable chair. Have fabrics sent up from Lannisport. My lady likes to make her own clothes.” His heart was racing, thrilled at the prospect of having her here, beside him.

 

“Shall we have a new bed brought in?”

 

“Not for this room, but a new mattress for our room,” he said firmly. He gestured for Lucion to follow him and brought him into the desolate solar of the Lord’s chambers. “Have the sofas reupholstered and the wood refinished. Fresh flowers in here every day. Have a cloak made for my wedding ceremony.” He rubbed a hand over his chin. “I’m sure I’m forgetting things but we have time.”

 

“Yes, my Lord. I’ll get started on these items. Anything, in particular, you’d like for the feast?”

 

“Lemon cakes,” he said with a smile. “She loves lemon cakes.”

Chapter End Notes

Arya is next for a wedding in KL and then off to Winterfell. Sansa's chapter will follow and you will see all the parts leading up to her eventual arrival at CR.

Arya XIV

Chapter Summary

Arya experiences nerves on the eve of her wedding about being a wife and mother. Arya and Gendry get married and travel to Winterfell for Bran's wedding to Meera.

Chapter Notes

Thanks to justwanderingneverlost for the gorgeous mood board.

Also, thank you to everyone for that overwhelming response to the last chapter. I'm so glad I could make you all happy with that conclusion. And with the next chapter, you will see Sansa's side of it.

As for the timeline - Here's what's happening all around the same time.
Jaime leaves the morning of Arya's wedding to head back to Casterly Rock. Bran, Meera, and Sansa are all in Winterfell and don't yet know of Lord Selwyn's visit, but you'll get that in the next chapter when Bran informs Brienne and Tormund. When Arya arrives in Winterfell it is three weeks since they left King's Landing. Sansa has not yet received Jaime's letter or responded to it, he has not yet arrived in Casterly Rock, but he is close. Jon and Dany are doing some council stuff, but we'll catch up with them when we next see Jon.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

ARYA


She came out of the en-suite to find Gendry standing on the balcony looking down at the city. She could see fires lit at the party for the coronation still raged on, and even in the homes spread throughout the city. Arya hated the way the city seemed to smell, even though the scent was partially covered up while in the Red Keep. She put a hand on his back and he turned to her, a dark look on his face.


“You alright?”


He frowned. “Just thinking about Flea Bottom. Wondering how much of what happened today they actually cared about? How much of what was left got to the people that truly needed it?”


She huffed out a sigh. “Probably not enough. But you know that Jon and Daenerys are going to try to make their lives better.”


“They’ll try. But it seems to me that the people at the bottom always get trampled on.” She tensed and was ready to defend her brother and he held up a hand. “I know. I do. I know Jon and Daenerys. I know that if anyone is going to accomplish that goal it will be them. I’ve just seen a lot of people not care.”


“That’s not who they are. That’s not who we are.” She cupped his cheek. “They’re already working to make things better. Both of them suffered through horrid pasts. I think if anyone can understand the plight of people who are stomped on it’s Jon and Daenerys.”


He nodded. “I know you’re right. I believe in them. It’s the rest of the world I doubt.”


“I believe the two of them will be able to accomplish great things. They're stubborn, determined, people love them, and they now have six dragons. Daenerys always talked about breaking the wheel that turns over people. I think they’ll do exactly what they claim.”


He pressed a kiss to her forehead. “It’s rare for me to be the pessimistic one and you to reassure me.”


She shrugged and wrapped her arms around his waist. “You left me no choice. Besides, I had a feeling that being back in the city would cause you to have some odd feelings.”


He snorted. “Counted on that, did you?”


“I know you, is all. It’s good that you remember what it was like to live like that. You can help make people’s lives better because of it.”


“Have I made your life better?”


She laughed and nodded. “Made me want things I thought I would never want.”


He kissed her lips this time and they started back toward the bed. “I want you,” he whispered.


She nodded and pulled his tunic over his head as he backed her up to the post at the foot. He pulled at the ties at the front of her shift and she pushed it off her shoulders to pool at her hips. His lips found the pulse in her throat as he pushed her shift completely to the floor. He chuckled against her skin.


“Why are you laughing?” she asked, tugging at the laces of his trousers.


“The perk of you wearing dresses is you never wear small clothes beneath them,” he finished the last word with a groan as she got his laces undone and had his cock in her hand. She licked at his lips before he took her mouth in another kiss, leaving her breathless as his hands slid sensuously over her body. She gasped when he suddenly lifted her from her feet to hold her against the bedpost. She wrapped an arm around his neck as he walked them to the mattress and climbed onto the bed. She wasn’t aware he had even removed his trousers.


He rolled to his back and she climbed on top of him, her knees squeezing into his sides as she pressed kisses to his neck. He tugged back on her hair and she gasped when she felt his teeth nip the pulse in her throat. She bit her lip and writhed on top of him, his hard cock trapped between them. He released her hips and stilled her, groaning against her skin. “You gotta stop that, Arya. We haven’t been like this since we left and I’m gonna spill like a green boy the way you’re moving.”


She leaned down to kiss him. “I suppose we could wait until we’re married tomorrow.”


“Fuck no,” he growled. “I want to be inside you.”


She pushed herself up and reached between them to grasp his cock. “I want that, too,” she said as spread the liquid from his leaking tip over him, then teased her little nub with it.


“Fuck sake, Arya! Mercy!” he said as he pressed his head back against the pillow and dug his fingers into her hips. She bit her lip as she ended their torment and guided him inside her. She rolled her hips against his, loving the way it always felt to have him inside her. She could feel the strength in his fingers, knowing he could guide her with his hands if he chose, but he let her set the pace.


She leaned forward, pressing her hands to the bed beside his head and began bouncing over him. His hands started exploring her skin. Each trail of his fingers leaving gooseflesh in its wake. She shivered above him lost in the feel of his hands, mouth, and body as they cherished her. Her breath caught in her throat as his thumb pressed against the little nub. She threw her head back and went still as she crested against the edge then fell over it with the flicking of his thumb against her clit. She fell against his chest as she felt exhaustion in her bones and was barely cognizant of Gendry finishing.


With her head tucked between his chin and shoulder, she was nearly asleep when he rolled her to her side and he stood from the bed and went to the water basin. “What’re you doing?” Her words felt slurred and she tried to keep her eyes opened as he returned to the bed with a wet flannel in his hand.


“Seeing as you’re already falling asleep, I’m going to clean you up and then join you. It’s been a long day,” he muttered as he cleaned the mess from between her legs. The next thing she knew, the bed shifted and Gendry was pulling her closer to sleep in their normal position. She had dreams about hundreds of babies crying and she was powerless to stop any of them.


*~*


Davos had come by early in the morning to drag Gendry away from their cozy bed and to a different part of the castle. Jon showed up not long after to have her come spend the day with him and Daenerys. She really wanted to stay in bed and try to fight off the sickness she felt. Once her dress had been gathered and taken to their chamber, however, she was left with little option but to follow.


She felt miserable and promptly laid down on Jon’s bed and dozed for a little while. It wasn’t until Daenerys entered the room that the dragons squawked and woke her. She could see it was now midday and she had two royals staring at her with large smiles.


“How are you feeling?”


“Tired and sick,” she admitted as she sat up and brushed down her hair. “Where did Davos take Gendry?”


“Don’t know,” Jon admitted. “He asked permission from us to not be our Hand today in order to be there for your future husband.”


“Naturally, we agreed,” Daenerys said as she sat on the edge of the bed beside her and Arya shook her head in amazement. “You can say it: I’m huge.”


“No...well, I mean, you have babies in there. Sansa told me there were two in a letter. But what does it feel like?”


Daenerys rubbed a hand over her belly and Arya stared at her with apprehension. “At first, like you feel now. Tired, achy, irritable, and sick. And then, one day, you feel this...little flutter. Gendry won’t be able to feel it for a while, but you feel it, and you know that it’s the baby. Like...butterfly wings flapping,” she said softly. “That gives way to actually feeling kicks and twists from arms and legs,” she said with a chuckle. “And you constantly have to relieve yourself and you’re always hot.”


“Occasionally cranky.” They both looked at Jon who was giving them a teasing smile.


“You hush. Have a human kick your bladder and see how great you feel.”


“No thank you. I’ll leave the childbearing to the stronger sex.”


“Oh! Sex is something you’ll crave! You won’t be able to get enough.”


Jon furrowed his brow. “When did we hit that phase?”


“We were on the road.”


“We could have stopped more often!”


“I’m going to be sick,” Arya groaned. They all grew quiet and she looked at her hands, afraid to actually give voice to her worries. “I’m afraid I won’t be a good mother.”


She could see Jon about to protest but Daenerys held up a hand and silenced him along with a look. “Tell me why you feel that way?”


She huffed out a breath and stood. “Because a part of me never wanted this. I’m a fighter, a trained assassin. This was...I thought this was more suited to someone like Sansa and the part of me that remembers growing up in her shadow doesn’t want the things that she wants. I wanted to defy all of that, be beyond it. I wanted to be better. But now I’m going to have all of the things I swore to father I would never want.”


“How old were you when you swore that?”


“Old enough that I remember the disappointment on his face when I said it. Even though he supported my sword training, he still thought I might fall in line and this would be my life.”


“Do you hate your life? Do you hate being with Gendry? Do you hate living in Storm’s End? Do you hate that you’re having a child or marrying him?” Daenerys asked.


She shook her head. “No. I love my life. I love him and this baby. I want to marry him because I love him. But is this it? All I’ll be? A mother and a wife?”


Daenerys frowned. “Is that what you think of me? A mother and a wife?”


She shook her head. “No. You’re the queen. A Targaryen Queen.”


“And you’re an assassin, a warrior, a sister, a daughter, a Stark, a lover. Being one of those doesn’t mean you have to stop being any of the others.”


“It’s just not what I expected.”


Jon took her hand. “None of us are where we thought we would be. By all rights, we should all probably be dead, but we aren’t. With you, Daenerys, Yara, Sansa, Meera, Brienne,” he said with a smile, “women are proving every day that they can exceed expectations and wield amazing power effortlessly. You will always be who you want to be, Arya. Even when you knew it was wrong, you still pushed against the world to make your own way. This is your way.”


She thought back on her conversation with Brienne all those months ago about how she was both a warrior and a woman who loved a man. She could be both. “Alright, enough trying to convince me,” she muttered. “Just tell me one thing.” Daenerys nodded for her to continue. “tell me I’ll stop being sick soon.”


Her good-sister chuckled and wrapped an arm around her shoulders. “Oh, I wish I could. Unfortunately, every woman is different.”


“Great.”

When she got out of the bath, she found her dress spread out over their bed with the other woman holding two of the dragons, another curled on her shoulder and the one named after her on the table playing loudly with a goblet.

“Missandei,” called the soft voice.


“I’ve asked her to help you get ready. I would but I get winded easily.”


Arya nodded and Daenerys bid her enter.


“Arya,” Missandei greeted her.


“Missandei,” she said with a smile.


“Is this your dress?” she asked as she gestured to the grey one draped across the bed. “It’s similar to the one Sansa made for you.”


“I like the cut of that one so I had a similar one made.”


The dark dress was lined with fur, paying homage to her family and their love for wolves. It wasn’t typical colors for a wedding, the dress black with gold trim. “It’s beautiful,” Daenerys said with a smile. “I did note one thing, though. You didn’t bring a shift.”

She shrugged. “It’s one of the reasons he likes it when I wear dresses.”


Daenerys chuckled. “I think you’ll be perfectly happy in your marriage.”

“That would help.”
